story:
New York City'de bulunan Pratt Institute, Mimarlık Yüksek Lisans programına burslu kabul aldım! Ne yazık ki bu, eğitime başlayabilmem için yeterli değil. 



Merhaba, ben Aslıhan. Pratt Institute, Mimarlık Yüksek Lisans (M.Arch) programına 23.000$ bursla kabul aldım. Ne yazık ki bana verilen burs okul ücretini karşılamaya yetmiyor. Büyük bir heyecanla sürdürdüğüm akademik hayatım için önemli bir dönüm noktasındayım. Ve bu eşiği aşabilmek için katkılarınıza ihtiyacım var. 
***

  

İhtiyacım olan;

Okul ücreti ve okulun öngördüğü masraflarla birlikte bursun üzerine ödemem gereken miktar 20.000$. 



New York'ta bir öğrenci olarak sadece okulda çalışma imkanım olacak, bu sayede yaşam masraflarımın bir kısmını karşılayabiliyor olacağım. Ne yazık ki eğitimime başlayabilmem için gereken 20.000$'lık bütçeye sahip değilim. Bu noktada sizlerin desteğine ihtiyacım var!


Ben kimim?

2012 yılında İstanbul Teknik Üniversitesi İç Mimarlık Bölümü'nden mezun oldum. 2015 yılında ise %100 bursla okuduğum Kadir Has Üniversitesi İletişim Bölümleri Yüksek Lisans Programı'nı bitirdim. Yüksek lisans eğitimimin ardından İstanbul Teknik Üniversitesi Mimari Tasarım Doktora Programı'nda eğitime başladım. Şu an doktora eğitimimi sürdürüyorum. 2014 Kasım'dan beri de Işık Üniversitesi Güzel Sanatlar Fakültesi, İç Mimarlık Bölümü'nde Araştırma Görevlisi olarak akademik kariyer yolunda ilerliyorum.

Portfolyoma bakmak için; http://issuu.com/aslihanavci/docs/aslihanavciportfolio/1 

Doktora eğitimime Amerika'da devam edebilme isteğiyle başvurduğum bu program, benim için doktora yolunda çok önemli bir adım olacak.
Bu adımı atabilmem adına yapacağınız her katkı için şimdiden çok teşekkür ederim!
 



I got accepted into the Master of Architecture program with a scholarship at the Graduate Architecture and Urban Design: Pratt Institute! Unfortunately, it will not be enough to start my education.



Hello, I am Aslıhan. I got accepted into the Master of Architecture (M.Arch) program with a scholarship in the amount of $23,000. Unfortunately the scholarship will not be enough to fund my education. I am at the important turning point for my academic career that I pursue with a passion. And I need your contributions to overcome this threshold.   

***


What I Need:

Estimated cost of attendance made by the university:

As an international student in New York City, I will be able to work on-campus, so I will be able to meet some of my living expenses. Unfortunately, I do not have the budget for needed $20,000 to start my education. With my campaign, I will be raising money for the cost of attendance. At this point, I need your contribution!

Who Am I?

I graduated from Istanbul Technical University, department of Interior Architecture in 2012. I was accepted to Kadir Has University, Communication Studies master program with %100 scholarship and graduated in 2015. After my gradute studies, I have started my Ph.D education in Architectural Design at Istanbul Technical University. Currently I continue studying for my Ph.D education. I am now moving towards an academic career as a research assistant in the department of Interior Architecture at Faculty of Fine Arts in Isik University.


To look my portfolio; http://issuu.com/aslihanavci/docs/aslihanavciportfolio/1 


M.Arch program will be very important step towards my academic career which I applied with a desire to continue my Ph.D education in the United States. 

Through your generosity, you will be helping me step into my career path next. And I thank you in advance for all your contributions!
story_txt:
New York City'de bulunan Pratt Institute, Mimarlık Yüksek Lisans programına burslu kabul aldım! Ne yazık ki bu, eğitime başlayabilmem için yeterli değil. 



Merhaba, ben Aslıhan. Pratt Institute, Mimarlık Yüksek Lisans (M.Arch) programına 23.000$ bursla kabul aldım. Ne yazık ki bana verilen burs okul ücretini karşılamaya yetmiyor. Büyük bir heyecanla sürdürdüğüm akademik hayatım için önemli bir dönüm noktasındayım. Ve bu eşiği aşabilmek için katkılarınıza ihtiyacım var. 
***

  

İhtiyacım olan;
Okul ücreti ve okulun öngördüğü masraflarla birlikte bursun üzerine ödemem gereken miktar 20.000$. 






New York'ta bir öğrenci olarak sadece okulda çalışma imkanım olacak, bu sayede yaşam masraflarımın bir kısmını karşılayabiliyor olacağım. Ne yazık ki eğitimime başlayabilmem için gereken 20.000$'lık bütçeye sahip değilim. Bu noktada sizlerin desteğine ihtiyacım var!


Ben kimim?

2012 yılında İstanbul Teknik Üniversitesi İç Mimarlık Bölümü'nden mezun oldum. 2015 yılında ise %100 bursla okuduğum Kadir Has Üniversitesi İletişim Bölümleri Yüksek Lisans Programı'nı bitirdim. Yüksek lisans eğitimimin ardından İstanbul Teknik Üniversitesi Mimari Tasarım Doktora Programı'nda eğitime başladım. Şu an doktora eğitimimi sürdürüyorum. 2014 Kasım'dan beri de Işık Üniversitesi Güzel Sanatlar Fakültesi, İç Mimarlık Bölümü'nde Araştırma Görevlisi olarak akademik kariyer yolunda ilerliyorum.



Portfolyoma bakmak için; http://issuu.com/aslihanavci/docs/aslihanavciportfolio/1 



Doktora eğitimime Amerika'da devam edebilme isteğiyle başvurduğum bu program, benim için doktora yolunda çok önemli bir adım olacak.


Bu adımı atabilmem adına yapacağınız her katkı için şimdiden çok teşekkür ederim!
 





I got accepted into the Master of Architecture program with a scholarship at the Graduate Architecture and Urban Design: Pratt Institute! Unfortunately, it will not be enough to start my education.





Hello, I am Aslıhan. I got accepted into the Master of Architecture (M.Arch) program with a scholarship in the amount of $23,000. Unfortunately the scholarship will not be enough to fund my education. I am at the important turning point for my academic career that I pursue with a passion. And I need your contributions to overcome this threshold.   
***


What I Need:
Estimated cost of attendance made by the university:



As an international student in New York City, I will be able to work on-campus, so I will be able to meet some of my living expenses. Unfortunately, I do not have the budget for needed $20,000 to start my education. With my campaign, I will be raising money for the cost of attendance. At this point, I need your contribution!


Who Am I?
I graduated from Istanbul Technical University, department of Interior Architecture in 2012. I was accepted to Kadir Has University, Communication Studies master program with %100 scholarship and graduated in 2015. After my gradute studies, I have started my Ph.D education in Architectural Design at Istanbul Technical University. Currently I continue studying for my Ph.D education. I am now moving towards an academic career as a research assistant in the department of Interior Architecture at Faculty of Fine Arts in Isik University.

To look my portfolio; http://issuu.com/aslihanavci/docs/aslihanavciportfolio/1 

M.Arch program will be very important step towards my academic career which I applied with a desire to continue my Ph.D education in the United States. 
Through your generosity, you will be helping me step into my career path next. And I thank you in advance for all your contributions!

story:
My name is Myron Moorehead and I am the Founder and CEO of ProCare Counseling. ProCare Counseling is the first ever Pro-Active Addiction Counseling and Opioid Education Business in the entire U.S. 

The Prescription Drug Epidemic 

"What's the Problem"

The Real Problem is no one is looking at the Flow!  What is the Flow? The Flow is the initial Flow of good patients that are put on opioids for the First Time without any directions or education on how to use or not use this medication, other than "take it 3 or 4 times a day", a couple of labels stuck on their medication bottle and a lot of worthless paper stapled to the prescription bag, that no one Reads.  This Good Patient, which is described above becomes a Prescription Drug Misuser, then a Prescription Drug Abuser and finally, a Prescription Drug Addict.  If they are real Unlucky, they can become a Heroin Addict.  More people should ask the question "Why does a Good Patient turn into a Bad Patient??" The answer is a Lack of EDUCATION &  COMMUNICATION  between Doctor and Patient.


What we must understand is that Pain Management is Growing (100+ million) and programs to combat addiction are "millions of people" behind. What we also have to understand is that addiction programs don't work! Anytime you take an addict out of his or her environment or element for a long period of time, they will be cured....hell, jail proves that! Throw the addict in jail for a year and when he is released he is cured and clean. Six months after he is back in his neighborhood, environment or element, he is an addict again. Why? Lack of Education. The addict hasn't been taught as to how to act or react in his neighborhood, so he falls back into his old traps. In conclusion, addiction programs don't work.    You Must Educate Chronic Pain Management Patients to understand that a 100% of their pain is not relievable, nor is it realistic or attainable. The Patient must understand the true goals of pain management....which is to reduce pain, and most importantly, increase his/her quality of life. By providing them Education and Counseling, the patient will learn and attain more realistic goals, and how to live life as a Chronic pain Patient.        

ProCare Counseling is a Pro-Active Addiction & Opioid Education Center, the idea came to me three years ago, while I owned and operated a large, successful pain management practice. This idea began to consume all of my free time until I felt I had to sell my pain clinic, and make ProCare my full-time job. I had no idea how large and important ProCare's Pro-Active Education would be to so many people. It was a great challenge to create this New Company that is dedicated to being Pro-Active about a huge problem in the health care industry.

ProCare was designed to give Patient's Individualized Opioid Education and Counseling and Provide a Risk Management Package to Physicians with Signatures of Understandings that will Make the Patient More Responsible for their Opioid therapy, thus Strengthening the Doctors Chart and Lowering the Physician's Risk of Treating that Patient.

Why is it So Difficult to Judge a Good Patient?  Some Patients are at Greater Risk for misuse, abuse, diversion, or addiction than others, but Identifying these Patients can be a Complex Task because there is No Clear Consensus on their Respective Definitions. Most Doctors Agree that Patients who take Opioids are Somewhere in Between: Those who Adhere to Their Treatment regimen and Those who Purposefully Abuse their medications.  On the Assumption that every patient has a degree of risk..... a Universal Precautions Approach is Suggested, beginning with a Thorough Risk Assessment for Every Patient who is prescribed opioids for chronic pain.

 The United States has 10 Strategies to Stop the Epidemic, all of the Strategies are Re-Active and Designed to Keep the Bad Patient From Getting Worse....

1. Drug Monitoring 2. Mandatory use of Drug Monitoring 3. Dr. Shopping Law 4. Medicaid Expanded Coverage of Substance Abuse 5. Prescriber Education 6. Good Samaritan Law 7. Support Rescue Drug Use 8. Physical Exam Requirement 9. ID Requirements 10. Pharmacy Lock-in Programs


How do we solve it?

Opioid Education Consists of…..About Opioids, Responsible Use, Opioids while Driving /Pregnant,

Pain Contracts, Opioid Side Effects, Missing a Dose, Signs of Over Dose, Storing Medication, etc....

Pro Active Addiction Counseling Helping your Patients identify issues and concerns before they turn into problems, thus keeping Your Good Patients Compliant Longer.

Signatures of Understandings will Make the Patient More Responsible for their Opioid therapy, thus Strengthening the Doctors Chart and Lowering the Physician's Risk of Treating that Patient.     

The Solution is not being re-active, nor is it controlling the bad patient with 10 Strategies.

The Solution to any Epidemic Begins with Education..... And the Solution is Pro-Active Addiction Counseling and Opioid Education.

Think of Pro Care as the Training Wheels on a bike. These wheels keep the new rider from falling while learning to ride.  Through quarterly visits, ProCare keeps the Good Patients Compliant longer with Opioid Education and One-on-One Pro-Active Addiction Counseling. Pro Care has been test marketed, with over 5000 visits completed.  Please join with us to Make Pro Care the Nation's Solution.


As Lovable as they come and as Cuddly as can be

 Get your ProCare Bear Now!

story:
Hola, Soy Carlos Burges Ruiz de Gopegui y he vendido más de 17.000 libros en la iBooks Store en estos 3 últimos años, todos ellos manuales técnicos sobre productos de Apple, productividad y tecnología.
 

Escribir un libro es uno de los objetivos que nos solemos marcar al empezar el año. En la práctica es muy complicado (y muy caro): encontrar editorial, plazos, distribución… la tecnología digital nos ayuda y nos permite publicar nuestros propios libros controlando todos los procesos y convirtiendo ese objetivo en una realidad. Si estás pensando en llevar adelante este objetivo, este curso es para ti.

En este curso veremos no solo nos la parte técnica y todo el proceso desde la creación de la idea y la motivación para llevarla acabo, sino también los problemas que nos podemos encontrar por el camino y toda la experiencia (como autor y editor) a la hora de rentabilizar tu trabajo.

El curso, de más de 10 horas, estará disponible en formato de video tutorial de alta calidad en 720p y 1080p acompañado de material de apoyo como libros adicionales, ejemplos y aplicaciones.

Cuando termines el curso dispondrás de toda la información teórica y práctica para llevar adelante tu libro (o libros), sino también el conocimiento para sacarle el mayor rendimiento a tu inversión de tiempo y dinero.

"Lo verdaderamente impresionante de Carlos Burges no es todo lo que sabe, sino su innata capacidad de transmitirlo a los demás de una manera clara y concisa, para conseguir que aprendamos y deseemos aprender más." Emilio Cano, Podcaster, responsable de la red de podcast Emilcar.fm

"Este curso ha sido imprescindible para poder llegar a lanzar mis publicaciones en la iBook Store. La experiencia que acumula y comparte Carlos en él es la linterna que necesitaba” Edén Expósito Montes de Oca, autor de libros en la iBooks Store.


El contenido de este curso, de más de 10 horas, incluye:


    •    Quiero escribir un libro
    ◦    Motivación y temática de tu libro


    •    Modelos de negocio
    ◦    Libros de creación propia (literatura)

    ◦    Aprovechar los mercados de nicho

    •    eBooks

story:
Contexte :

Une équipe de l’Université du Québec en Outaouais participera à la Simulation des Nations Unies (National Model United Nations) qui se déroulera à New York du 18 au 23 mars 2017. Cette simulation rassemblera plusieurs milliers d’étudiants en provenance du monde entier qui reproduisent, dans un contexte très réaliste, les travaux de l’Assemblée Générale des Nations Unies et de la diplomatie internationale. Les étudiants y participant en reviennent transformés et enrichis de nouvelles perspectives.

Il s'agit d'une opportunité en or pour faire rayonner l'UQO ainsi que l’Outaouais dans le monde entier.

Appel à tous :

Nous faisons appel à vous afin d’amasser des fonds pour nous permettre de vivre cette expérience. Certains facteurs font en sorte que la collecte de fonds est plus difficile que les autres années puisque, entre autres, le taux de change avec le dollar des États-Unis est très désavantageux.

Mandat :

Cette année, l’UQO représente le Honduras, un petit pays d’Amérique Centrale. Nous travaillerons sur divers comités rattachés à l’Assemblée générale de l’ONU. Nous traiterons de plusieurs sujets d’actualité en plus de chercher des solutions innovatrices, tels le rôle des femmes dans le maintien de la paix, la pauvreté, les désastres naturels, le développement durable, l’accès à l’éducation, le commerce illégal et les déchets nucléaires.

Frais :

Les frais pour ce voyage s’élèvent à environ 15 500 $. Ce montant inclut l’inscription à l’activité, le logement et le transport à New York. Le taux de change n’est pas à notre avantage en ce moment; ce qui fait en sorte que le défi est d’autant plus grand pour réunir cette somme.

Grâce à nos généreux donateurs, les associations étudiantes, les modules, le Décanat des études de l’UQO, la Fondation Desjardins et plus, nous avons jusqu’à présent amassé plus de 6000 $. Nous sommes encore à 9000 $ de notre rêve!

Plusieurs d’entre nous sommes dans une situation financière précaire. Votre soutien va permettre ainsi à toute notre délégation de se déplacer pour cette opportunité unique qui autrement aurait été inabordable. Votre contribution pourrait ainsi transformer nos opportunités de carrière et nos vies.

En guise de remerciement :

En guise de remerciement pour les dons que nous recevrons, nous offrirons, pour tous les dons, notre immense gratitude. Pour tous les dons de 25$ et plus, une carte postale de New York signée par la délégation complète. Pour les dons de 50$ et plus, nous publierons une vidéo sur notre page Facebook vous remerciant publiquement de votre don. 


Ce n’est pas tout! Vous connaissez un talent caché chez l’un de nos délégués qui mériterait d’être dévoilé? Vous voulez nous mettre au défi? Laissez aller votre imagination et regroupez vos dons pour ajouter du piquant à cette collecte de fonds. Envoyez-nous vos défis à s.a.lemieux@hotmail.com. Une fois que nous aurons accepté votre défi, vous devrez faire un don de 100$. Nous ferons ensuite une vidéo du défi à New York portant votre nom et nous la publierons sur notre page Facebook. 

 

Nous vous remercions de votre intérêt ainsi que de vos dons,

Diane Azie

Karine Bourgeau

Mélissa Bourgie

Nicolas Dimitropoulos

Maxime Drolet

Sophie Lemieux

Marie-Élise L’espérance

Erna Mehanovic

Virginie Moncion

Olivier St-Jacques

Grâce à nos généreux donateurs, les associations étudiantes, les modules, le Décanat des études de l’UQO, la Fondation Desjardins et plus, nous avons jusqu’à présent amassé plus de 6000 $. Nous sommes encore à 9000 $ de notre rêve!
Plusieurs d’entre nous sommes dans une situation financière précaire. Votre soutien va permettre ainsi à toute notre délégation de se déplacer pour cette opportunité unique qui autrement aurait été inabordable. Votre contribution pourrait ainsi transformer nos opportunités de carrière et nos vies.
En guise de remerciement : 
En guise de remerciement pour les dons que nous recevrons, nous offrirons, pour tous les dons, notre immense gratitude. Pour tous les dons de 25$ et plus, une carte postale de New York signée par la délégation complète. Pour les dons de 50$ et plus, nous publierons une vidéo sur notre page Facebook vous remerciant publiquement de votre don. 
Ce n’est pas tout! Vous connaissez un talent caché chez l’un de nos délégués qui mériterait d’être dévoilé? Vous voulez nous mettre au défi? Laissez aller votre imagination et regroupez vos dons pour ajouter du piquant à cette collecte de fonds. Envoyez-nous vos défis à s.a.lemieux@hotmail.com. Une fois que nous aurons accepté votre défi, vous devrez faire un don de 100$. Nous ferons ensuite une vidéo du défi à New York portant votre nom et nous la publierons sur notre page Facebook. 
 
Nous vous remercions de votre intérêt ainsi que de vos dons,
Diane Azie
Karine Bourgeau
Mélissa Bourgie
Nicolas Dimitropoulos
Maxime Drolet
Sophie Lemieux
Marie-Élise L’espérance
Erna Mehanovic
Virginie Moncion
Olivier St-Jacques

story:
Hey everybody! My name is Pete Welty and I'm the President of Cyrus Foundation, an educational nonprofit organization. It was about five years ago, I was between jobs and a friend of mine who owned a small music store with a thriving lessons program invited me to teach guitar. I loved it! It was so fun building relationships with these awesome young people and I discovered that our relationship was much more than "guitar teacher/guitar student", it was more of a mentoring role with these bright kids. I soon discovered that my friend's lessons program had been almost twice the size just a few years before but was now seeing dramatic decline. He also told me that as the schools were dropping more and more of their music programs, there was still a strong desire from kids and their parents to learn music. However, after the economic recession of 2008, fewer and fewer families could afford private music lessons. I began to do some research on the benefits of a music education and was overwhelmed with what I found. Students who learn music actually develop their brains in a unique and very beneficial way. Watch our video to learn more about that.

Having a background with nonprofits I suggested that we start a nonprofit organization so that we could build up a scholarship program for families that could no longer afford lessons or perhaps could never afford lessons before without some kind of financial assistance.

My friend has offered to sell his music shop and lessons program to us for HALF its estimated value so that we can run the entire enterprise under the nonprofit company. Therefore, all proceeds from the music store will now go to the scholarship fund.

A few years ago we were able to build a really great little recording studio right next door to the shop, so we can now offer lessons in recording, producing and mixing to those who are interested in that aspect of the music business.

I am joined in these efforts by my two partners, Ralph Burnett and Peter Johnson. Ralph is in charge of the recording studio where he will not only teach recording arts and composition to students but also establishing a record label and publishing company so that artists and students can share and promote their music with the proceeds going to the scholarship fund as well. Ralph is a Music Supervisor and Composer for Television and Film and former Products Manager of MCA Records/ Universal Music in L.A., and brings a great deal of knowledge about the music industry to our company. Peter is our business mind. With a successful background in business, he is also a musician and a songwriter and has found that our vision is one he can get behind passionately and has dedicated this chapter of his career to it.

Today we are attempting to raise $50,000.00 to get our vision off the ground and really moving. This money will be used as follows:

1. $20,000.00 to pay off the purchase of existing program.

2. $10,000.00 to go immediately into the scholarship fund.

3. $10,000.00 to seed ongoing fundraising efforts.

4. $7,000.00 to purchase  much needed instruments and equipment for our students to begin learning and sharing their music.

5. $3,000.00 to pay money owed to talented and goodhearted professionals who have helped us with their expertise to this point, deferring payment until we raise the funds.

NOW...PLEASE KEEP READING! This is NOT an effort to launch a program in one location here in Auburn/Grass Valley CA. It is the beginning of a movement! We intend to create something that can be replicated anywhere there is the need.  Our goal is to open three locations within our first two years. From there...? the sky's the limit. We see this program in communities all over the US and beyond. While cultures and governments may not place a high value on music education, WE DO! And we know that you do as well. Please give as generously as you can today to help get this much needed program the start it deserves.

story:
Inside the Addicted Mind

 

Why

Ask someone to describe an addict to you and you’ll most likely get a response along the lines of “a homeless person shooting up”. But this grimy image we’ve been taught is far from the truth. Most addictions are hard to spot and can go unnoticed for many years. Having dealt with this first-hand I felt it important to shine a light on the matter because if untreated, or ignored, it can lead to unpredictable circumstances.

  • Behind the scene images when we shot the "mind" scenes

 

How

The project features three 360° films that follow characters based on real stories and portray how addictions can come about and what the signs of addictions are. The films are also accompanied by an informative “extra” film that explores the topic in more depth correlating back to the three films. The way the films are shot was also an experimental VR technique which uses stills shot stitched together to form 360 image and transformed into a moving image.  

  • The timeline of my MA project

 

MA studies

I created this project for my Masters study but it has become something much more personal to me. Because of the emotional commitment I’ve put in, I want to make this as professionally as possible. The end goal for this project is to become a free educational tool for schools to show to 14-18 year olds and open the discussion surrounding the topic. I’ve self-funded the project up to this point, selling my things on a flea market to pay both for tuition and the initial production cost, but what this project needs is just one final push to reach the end goal and for that I need your help.

  • Mockup for how final version looks without VR headsets 

 

Addaction

I have partnered up with a charity called Addaction and the aim is to publish a dedicated app that can be used on any smartphone. We have a working prototype that I built myself but there is cost of publishing an official app. Accompanying the app I want to create custom VR Cardboard viewers to allow better immersion and help bring VR to more people. Lastly, I want to use the funding for marketing since there is no point trying to help if no one know that the project exists.

 

Challenges so far

I’ve had to teach myself to become a film editor, director, sound technician and many other skills. But I’ve obviously not mastered these skills and need extra hands to finish this. With your help, I can finish the project: by having professional colour grading done on the films, the feel of them is improved and more professional; a re-worked script would make the narration less passive and involve the audience; a final informational film would fulfil the educational aspect of the project.

  • Behind the scene, utilizing friends and family as assistants.   

 

How can you help

If you want to help out with the project in any other way than donations and have marketing, media or professional skill set, you can contact me at elvar@studiosig.com. And don’t forget the share buttons.

NB: Travel expenses aren’t included in the contribution. To attend the Private View, you need to be able to get to Bournemouth by your own means.

story:
Teaching the next generation, us parents and educators face an enormous challenge: how can we educate children that were connected to digital devices virtually through their umbilical cord? Many of them get their first tablet in nursery school. They grow up in a world where teaching in traditional ways is considered boring, and as a result it proves much more difficult. We need something interesting to engage these children, designated “Generation Alpha”.

Brainiac is a digital school with a growing number of interactive, educational stories. Each story consists of 6 episodes, the first of which is free of charge, and the rest are bought through in-app purchases. These stories can be played exclusively through the Brainiac application. This digital school makes learning more entertaining and more effective by using the gamification method: users need to collect as many “neuron connections” as possible. Through entertaining interactive stories and engaging activities, we enable 5-11 year-old children to establish a strong foundation for a successful adulthood.

We employ the gamification method. One definition is “the application of game-design elements and game principles in non-game contexts”. To us, it means endless entertainment. Players must collect virtual neuron connections by solving interactive mini-games (such as puzzles, memory games or hidden object games). The more neuron connections they collect, the more developed their soft skills become. Brainiac supports players with rich content that can be played multiple times. As such, in the event of replaying the stories, players develop more and more connections. Skills that are primarily developed are those, which are important for a successful life (memory, motor, language, organizational and social skills, time & money management and healthy life-style).

INTERACTIVE STORIES

THE FACTORY

Help Thomas succeed against all odds, and learn about robotics. Curriculum: Science (the human body), English, Math

TEAM TERRA

Start your magical journey of the galaxy, and learn about teamwork. Curriculum: Science (astronomy), Geography, Math

FANTASY FOREST FRIENDS

Follow our little group of friends into the city, and learn about transportation. Curriculum: Science (plants/animals), English, Math

By presenting entertaining learning games and activities as exciting and challenging as Brainiac, we capture kids' natural curiosity and get them excited about solving interactive mini-games. This way they end up having fun while learning.

AGE-APPROPRIATE CURRICULUM

We believe that the world is a big system. As such we try to construct our interactive stories in a way that encompasses several topics and not rigidly tied to one specific school subject. We focus on issues from these various subjects:

All our interactive stories comply with UK Key stages 1 and 2 standards. UK and US educators assisted in compiling the material, while award-winning writers helps us create the stories. Partners that helped us with fact checking and the final design of our educational curriculum include UNESCO and the European Space Agency.

Parents and educators should be aware of the content children will be exposed to. Educational guides, prepared by education experts, are attached to each story.

They contain:

  • Description of the characters
  • Description of the universe of the story
  • Quizzes and other games
  • Description of the main topic
  • Educational aspects
  • Activity guide

Tamas holds degrees in Economics and Art History. He has been working in the educational sector for seventeen years, with over ten years of teaching experience across a broad range of organizations, including exhibition centres, museums, art galleries and primary schools. Tamas worked as an organizer on big-budget educational touring exhibitions and as a guide for primary and secondary school groups, as well as a contributor and advisor for educational programs and guides.

We are raising $20,000 to create stories. The money will go towards:

  1. Creating more interactive stories
  2. Further developing the app framework

Exceeding our goal will help us design more and more interactive stories. You can get many exciting rewards, including unlocking complete interactive stories and the option of purchasing future stories, and even brand t-shirts.

Software development takes time, and there is always a chance for delay; however, we do not anticipate delaying Brainiac’s update.

We want every child to have the opportunity of getting a cutting-edge education so we can have a world with kids who are more open and clever, doing amazing things!

We understand that not everyone can contribute financially, but you can still help us by spreading the word! You can use the share tools on this page to share with your friends. That is just as valuable to us as your financial contribution, and we thank you for helping us in any way you can. One of the easiest places to share is via social media!

Have suggestions or ideas? Feel free to contact us, we would love to hear from you!

BRAINIAC: A SUBSTITUTE FOR SCHOOL?

No, but it certainly completes school. We work together with working professionals and educators, as we believe that school subjects can be taught in an interesting way (admittedly not in the same way as they do it in school).

WHY STORIES, WHY GAMIFICATION?

There is an extremely wide array of choices regarding how to pass on knowledge. We feel stories are the best way to set about, as we honestly believe that it is much easier to both learn and retain knowledge when it is taught through a STORY. Gamification means rewarding, which is completely understandable, as most people would feel much more motivated when there’s a prize involved.

WHO ARE YOUR EDUCATION EXPERTS?

We count on the expertise of UK and US primary school headmasters and principals. They help us develop the standards we use. We have also contacted experts from UNESCO and the European Space Agency, both being highly esteemed international organizations.

story:
"What we do for ourselves dies with us, what we do for others and the world remains and is immortal "

(Robert Pike 1809-1891)

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

The tragedy is that the Cambodian legacy is not only archeological, as its history is linked with its horrific genocide. Some 2 millions souls were murdered under the bloody regime of the Khmer Rouge - 2 millions lives stolen in the most horrific way, women, children, elderly…

A less known fact was the Khmer Rouge's policy of systematic extermination of all forms of religious, cultural and traditional legacy, killing 90% of artists dancers, musiciens, historians.  

It is in this distressing context that our story began, in a few villages around the temple of Banteay Srei, which were still in 1999 under the control of the Khmer Rouge, in the heart of the Khmer cultural heritage site of Angkor – a UNESCO World Heritage Site.

 

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

This is how it all started

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Our story centres around the determination of a woman called Ravynn Karet-Coxen, who after two decades in exile in Europe, had decided to go back to her homeland to contribute during the reconstruction from this unspeakable tragedy. 

In 1994 Ravynn set up in London, where she lives, the  Foundation Nginn Karet for Cambodia (www.nkfc.org), travelling twice a year to Cambodia to identify where the most contribution was needed. She journeyed through the countryside trying to figure out how and where to help, and organised 2 major fundraising events: 1999 in London, and 2000 in New York where  she gathered enough funds, 1 million American dollars, to begin the sustainable work in the 14 chosen villages in the heart of the Khmer cultural heritage of Angkor where the population were the most deprived and in a deep psychological distress.

In 1999 when it all started, some of the villages were still under the control of the Khmer Rouge and for the first 6 months had to work under curfew. 

Eighteen years later her gamble has surpassed all her hopes, deploying all the energy, strength and determination, without a day of rest, nor a stress free night, hand in hand with the local authorities, villagers and her wonderful staff, NKFC managed to bring 2868 families (around 20,000 people) of the 14 villages of the District of Banteay Srei  to a dignified and sustainable livelihood. 

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

The birth of the Sacred Dancers of Angkor

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

 


In 2007, the first rural Khmer traditional dance and music school saw light. In a country still traumatised by the extermination of those who carried the  cultural knowledge transmitted orally, where the scars of the genocide perpetuated by the Khmer Rouges are still palpable in the mutilated souls. The creation of this traditional dance and music school has proven to be an important psychological healing factor reconciling the  families with their traditions and cultural values.

In Cambodia, dance is neither a mere discipline nor is it entertainment. It is a timeless language that flows in the Cambodian veins, nourishing the souls of the people, it is a means to communicate with the Gods, celebrating them and thanking them.

The Conservatoire of dance and music was a turning point to the Foundation as they discovered that all their previous efforts just improved physical being -  homes, crops, water supply, hygiene but still the eyes were empty, stone cold like beads. The medium of music and dance revived buried strengths and the memories of their cultural knowledge which were punished by death penalties during the Khmer Rouge period. It slowly liberated them from the state of limbo that they were forced to adopt for their own survival. 

Fitting to their profile of humble artists born and trained in the sacred land around their temple - a spiritual dimension was added to their curriculum of classical, folk and traditional music to give them a specific identity. All the artists piously meditate and pray daily before their trainings for the Peace in the World and the Welfare of Children beside dedicating rituals to reinstate the spiritual energy in the temples as well as profound rites for the souls of horrendrous devastation in the World. 

In ten years of daily training, five days a week, six hours per day, learning, repeating rehearsing and refining the most incredible and rare full length repertoires of the classical ballet, the Sacred Dancers of Angkor are accomplished artists mastering also the folk dance and traditional music. An extraordinary achievement from children who 10 years ago did not know what dance was about. 

The unique talent and spiritual dedication of the Sacred Dancers of Angkor has gained the support of His Majesty King Sihamoni and the Patronage of HRH Princess Buppha Devi, legendary Prima Ballerina and Cambodian Living legend of Dance.  



In the last 10 years the dancers and musicians have dedicated spiritual rites in 32 major Angkorian temples - as far as Was Phou in Laos; have performed in United States from East to West to marvelled audiences; received standing ovations and soon will be going to Japan. 

The Sacred Dancers of Angkor built its credentials in the strength and energy transmitted to bring Peace in the World through their daily dedication. It is  through the power and concentration of meditation and prayer that each of the artists is piously sending messages around the World. 

 The charismatic illumination of the Sacred Dancers is slowly gaining recognition around the world, triggering many demands to see them perform .

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

The survival of the Sacred Dancers of Angkor

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Their Conservatoire of Dance and Music is located one hour by  car from Siem Reap, near the temple of Banteay Srei in the Angkor archeological Park where visiting hours are strictly controlled. 

In 2015, despite a growing popularity and an increased radiance the Conservatoire was hit by a perilous situation due to its rural location far away from the heart of Siem Reap town where all visitors stay after a whole day of visit in the Angkor Park. The artists born and trained there face a dilemma. After 10 years of daily training, now young adults many are obliged to find a means to survive and help support their destitute large families by earning dangerously and unsafely in brick factories, construction sites, fields and even illegally in Thailand as low paid workers. 

Ravynn, far from being disconcerted, is trying,  as she always has done for the last 20 years, to find a solution. She has envisioned a little theatre in the heart of the town of Siem Reap easily accessible to all visitors eager to discover the unique talent of passionate and dedicated artists but also to share the authentic delicate beauty of the dance legacy.

This proposal is closely linked on the survival and the sustainability of the troupe It is where they would introduce and share the most authentic legacy of the classical dance. To this effect US$55,000 is needed to set up this accessible little theatre on the banks of the Siem Reap River, at the back of a traditional wooden house between the EFEO “Ecole Française d’Extrême Orient” and the Conservation d’Angkor, between two of the oldest pagodas Wat Preah Enn Kosa and Wat Preah Enn Kaosei, exclusively reserved for the Sacred Dancers of Angkor to give regular performances in all their independence and autonomy.

YOU MUST BE THE CHANGE YOU WISH TO SEE IN THE WORLD

Ghandi !
story_txt: "What we do for ourselves dies with us, what we do for others and the world remains and is immortal " (Robert Pike 1809-1891)------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------The tragedy is that the Cambodian legacy is not only archeological, as its history is linked with its horrific genocide. Some 2 millions souls were murdered under the bloody regime of the Khmer Rouge - 2 millions lives stolen in the most horrific way, women, children, elderly…A less known fact was the Khmer Rouge's policy of systematic extermination of all forms of religious, cultural and traditional legacy, killing 90% of artists dancers, musiciens, historians.  It is in this distressing context that our story began, in a few villages around the temple of Banteay Srei, which were still in 1999 under the control of the Khmer Rouge, in the heart of the Khmer cultural heritage site of Angkor – a UNESCO World Heritage Site. ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------This is how it all started----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Our story centres around the determination of a woman called Ravynn Karet-Coxen, who after two decades in exile in Europe, had decided to go back to her homeland to contribute during the reconstruction from this unspeakable tragedy. In 1994 Ravynn set up in London, where she lives, the  Foundation Nginn Karet for Cambodia (www.nkfc.org), travelling twice a year to Cambodia to identify where the most contribution was needed. She journeyed through the countryside trying to figure out how and where to help, and organised 2 major fundraising events: 1999 in London, and 2000 in New York where  she gathered enough funds, 1 million American dollars, to begin the sustainable work in the 14 chosen villages in the heart of the Khmer cultural heritage of Angkor where the population were the most deprived and in a deep psychological distress.In 1999 when it all started, some of the villages were still under the control of the Khmer Rouge and for the first 6 months had to work under curfew. Eighteen years later her gamble has surpassed all her hopes, deploying all the energy, strength and determination, without a day of rest, nor a stress free night, hand in hand with the local authorities, villagers and her wonderful staff, NKFC managed to bring 2868 families (around 20,000 people) of the 14 villages of the District of Banteay Srei  to a dignified and sustainable livelihood. ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------The birth of the Sacred Dancers of Angkor---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- In 2007, the first rural Khmer traditional dance and music school saw light. In a country still traumatised by the extermination of those who carried the  cultural knowledge transmitted orally, where the scars of the genocide perpetuated by the Khmer Rouges are still palpable in the mutilated souls. The creation of this traditional dance and music school has proven to be an important psychological healing factor reconciling the  families with their traditions and cultural values.In Cambodia, dance is neither a mere discipline nor is it entertainment. It is a timeless language that flows in the Cambodian veins, nourishing the souls of the people, it is a means to communicate with the Gods, celebrating them and thanking them.The Conservatoire of dance and music was a turning point to the Foundation as they discovered that all their previous efforts just improved physical being -  homes, crops, water supply, hygiene but still the eyes were empty, stone cold like beads. The medium of music and dance revived buried strengths and the memories of their cultural knowledge which were punished by death penalties during the Khmer Rouge period. It slowly liberated them from the state of limbo that they were forced to adopt for their own survival. Fitting to their profile of humble artists born and trained in the sacred land around their temple - a spiritual dimension was added to their curriculum of classical, folk and traditional music to give them a specific identity. All the artists piously meditate and pray daily before their trainings for the Peace in the World and the Welfare of Children beside dedicating rituals to reinstate the spiritual energy in the temples as well as profound rites for the souls of horrendrous devastation in the World. In ten years of daily training, five days a week, six hours per day, learning, repeating rehearsing and refining the most incredible and rare full length repertoires of the classical ballet, the Sacred Dancers of Angkor are accomplished artists mastering also the folk dance and traditional music. An extraordinary achievement from children who 10 years ago did not know what dance was about. The unique talent and spiritual dedication of the Sacred Dancers of Angkor has gained the support of His Majesty King Sihamoni and the Patronage of HRH Princess Buppha Devi, legendary Prima Ballerina and Cambodian Living legend of Dance.  In the last 10 years the dancers and musicians have dedicated spiritual rites in 32 major Angkorian temples - as far as Was Phou in Laos; have performed in United States from East to West to marvelled audiences; received standing ovations and soon will be going to Japan. The Sacred Dancers of Angkor built its credentials in the strength and energy transmitted to bring Peace in the World through their daily dedication. It is  through the power and concentration of meditation and prayer that each of the artists is piously sending messages around the World.  The charismatic illumination of the Sacred Dancers is slowly gaining recognition around the world, triggering many demands to see them perform .----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------The survival of the Sacred Dancers of Angkor----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Their Conservatoire of Dance and Music is located one hour by  car from Siem Reap, near the temple of Banteay Srei in the Angkor archeological Park where visiting hours are strictly controlled. In 2015, despite a growing popularity and an increased radiance the Conservatoire was hit by a perilous situation due to its rural location far away from the heart of Siem Reap town where all visitors stay after a whole day of visit in the Angkor Park. The artists born and trained there face a dilemma. After 10 years of daily training, now young adults many are obliged to find a means to survive and help support their destitute large families by earning dangerously and unsafely in brick factories, construction sites, fields and even illegally in Thailand as low paid workers. Ravynn, far from being disconcerted, is trying,  as she always has done for the last 20 years, to find a solution. She has envisioned a little theatre in the heart of the town of Siem Reap easily accessible to all visitors eager to discover the unique talent of passionate and dedicated artists but also to share the authentic delicate beauty of the dance legacy.This proposal is closely linked on the survival and the sustainability of the troupe It is where they would introduce and share the most authentic legacy of the classical dance. To this effect US$55,000 is needed to set up this accessible little theatre on the banks of the Siem Reap River, at the back of a traditional wooden house between the EFEO “Ecole Française d’Extrême Orient” and the Conservation d’Angkor, between two of the oldest pagodas Wat Preah Enn Kosa and Wat Preah Enn Kaosei, exclusively reserved for the Sacred Dancers of Angkor to give regular performances in all their independence and autonomy.------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------EXISTING SALA TO BE TRANSFORMED INTO LITTLE THEATRE( click here to enlarge the picture) NEEDS FOR THE SURVIVAL OF THE TROUPE( click here to enlarge the board )------------------------------------YOU MUST BE THE CHANGE YOU WISH TO SEE IN THE WORLDGhandi !

story:
Our mission

The first campaign was launched in 2014 and was a huge success - we raised enough money for two classes to go on the educational trip around Nepal. This time we want to raise enough money to send at least three more classes on the trip; Class 9 of 2017, 2018 & 2019. 

 

Briefly about VHMaVi School

Victor Hugo Manjushree Vidyapith (VHMaVi) school is a not-for-profit situated 15km north of Kathmandu city centre. It has 252 students, most of whom come from underprivileged families who cannot afford to pay tuition fees.

 

Why 'Travel2Educate'? What can you do to help? 

I, like so many others I have grown up with, have been fortunate enough to travel throughout my life. I began traveling as a young child, largely through school trips, and I have never really stopped. However, I only started to truly realise just how educational, inspiring, liberating, enriching and enlightening travelling is, when I started my 5 months volunteering at VHMaVi school in Kathmandu, Nepal in August 2014. During this time I was exposed first-hand to the harsh reality that so many children are denied this simple privilege that a lot of us take for granted.

We might not be able to eradicate world poverty, but together we can certainly give underprivileged children the opportunity to experience an educational trip of a lifetime. 

The Travel2Educate trip takes the children to some of the most frequented regions in Nepal, rich with history, museums and culture, and never before seen by the children:

- Chitwan

- Pokhara

- Bandipur

Having the chance to be a tourist for the first time in their own country can inspire the children to work in the travel/tourism industry, for example, which has a wealth of opportunities, offering thousands of different roles.

 

What will your money pay for?

5 x days

Chitwan eco-resort hotel + national park activities + museum

Pokhara eco-resort hotel + activities + culture house

Bandipur - stop over

Transport (private bus)

Food & drink 

 

How much does it cost?

£10 - 1 x student - travel fees

£30 - 1 x student - accommodation fees

£50 - 1 x student - full package

£350 - 7 x students (approx. half a class) - full package

£783 - 1 x class + 3 x volunteers/teachers - full package

Let's give these children an educational trip to remember - lets inspire, and bestow upon them the right to be educated through travel.

Thank you!

DONORS - Please send me a picture of you showing off your best tilaka so I can add you to the famous 'Wall of Enablers' - a tilaka is the red dot on the forehead usually made from red paste and is a Hindu tradition (see below for an example).

(above: beautiful women at Teej festival from my first visit in 2014)

You can email me at charlotte.l.sheldrake@gmail.com :)

The 'Wall of Enablers' is a collage of wonderful people, such as yourselves, who have donated their money to the campaign since it was first launched in 2014.

story:
We Want You to Recognize Africa's Potential

Imagine you invested in Walmart in 1970 because you were a friend of Sam Walton or Microsoft in 1986 because you personally knew Bill Gates.  Regardless of how much money you made, your investment helped change the world.


In Africa today there are entrepreneurs capable of creating innovative solutions that can change their world and ours for the better.  Never before has the convergence of technology, available capital, and socially conscious investors been so perfectly aligned to find and empower Africa’s greatest innovators.  The time is now! 

After working and living in Africa for so many years, I know this is true. I am so convinced that now is the time that I chose to retire from the US Air Force and put everything I have into making this vision a reality. Already I have helped eight amazing Africans start their own businesses, and I continue to collaborate with them as their fledgling businesses grow.

Take my friend Anselme. With the help of Africa Thryves, he began a marketing company that promotes other local businesses and helps them grow. He now employs four people and is helping them gain valuable skills that strengthen his business. Africa Thryves helped Anselme learn and apply the business principles necessary for him to earn a good profit every month that he reinvests back into the business – and he is only getting started. This is sustainable growth and prosperity, not a hand-out. Learn about Anselme's story in the video below! You will be amazed!

 

 

Be a part of the action as the next Anselme starts a business, and another, and another. You will get to know these innovators, follow them as they go to work, meet their families, see what daily life in Africa looks like up close and personal, and assist them as they make the world a better place. Now is the time to grab your front-row seat! Our packages are designed to be monthly subscriptions, but you can always purchase a package for a single month.  If your experience isn't what you hoped for, we'll refund your money!

Imagine it is 2030, and one of the African innovators you invested in solves the global energy crisis. Because you joined Africa Thryves, you had that front row seat, you were there with her through her struggles, failures, challenges, and victories. As the world celebrates the dawning of a new era of growth and prosperity, you know you played a role in the solution and you will still be there, working to create the next opportunity, whether it’s moving one family from poverty to employment or changing the whole world!

Your support will help start businesses in Africa while discovering unexplored future investment opportunities.  

What We Need & What You Get

We are seeking $30,000 to build on our current efforts and deploy our development system.  

Through our coaches and our investment club, you get a front-row seat into the realities, challenges, and opportunities of starting businesses in Africa.  Your support helps establish the habits of accountability and transparency in a diverse set of entrepreneurs who are working really hard to become successful.  Our packages cultivate an investment club environment which is focused on creating social impact.  They are designed to be monthly subscriptions, but you can always purchase a package for a single month and if your experience isn't what you hoped for, we'll refund your money!

Basic $25 Package

All packages create social equity which includes Interactive Giving, Personal Stories & Connections, and voting rights.  It allows you to feel a connection with each other and the entrepreneurs.  You are free to participate as much or as little as you like, but Africa Thryves is accountable to you.    

For $50 (Wear Your Impact), you:

  • Receive the monthly campaign T-shirt (begins mid-Sep 2019)
  • In early 2020 we will find and hire African artists to design the artwork for the monthly campaigns.  The artists will receive a commission during the first month and retain the selling rights through our website for future months (more jobs & more impact!)  Their shirts will remain for sale on our website

For $100 (Promote Your Impact), you:

  • Receive the promotional item branded with the Africa Thryves logo (begins mid-Sep 2019)
  • This is for business owners (or others) who have promotional needs.  We invite you to use our corporate promotions store to meet those needs.  This allows you to sample our products while supporting an awesome club.  As a club member, you will also receive a 10% discount on any purchase!
  • Products include popular shirts, backpacks, hats, pens and more.

For $500 (Advertise Your Impact), you:

  • Advertise on our website!  Leave positive impressions of your business or cause while building social and economic opportunities in Africa.

For $2,500 (Advertise Your Impact), you: 

  • Advertise in Africa!  Create a public message of hope & encouragement in the community you help.  For example, you could create a billboard "Stay Positive Africa! We are thinking of you!" Our prosperity coaches will later give you a report on the effectiveness/impact of your message.

For $5,000 (Advertise Your Impact), you:

  • Co-sponsor the monthly campaign T-Shirt.  The T-shirt will have up to 2 logos printed on the back of the monthly T-shirt (printing begins mid-Sep 2019). 
  • You can also sponsor the monthly promotional product.

If we don't reach our goal, all funds will still be used in the creation of Prosperity Pods.

The Impact

Our development system provides hope by improving the quantity and quality of entrepreneurs with a system of communal accountability and support.  Our five to seven-year commitment offers a timeline in which our efforts can bloom thereby creating an environment for generational change. 

Risks and Challenges

There are a myriad of risks, but we're up to the challenge!  We guarantee two things, 1) our very best efforts to coach these budding entrepreneurs and 2) some amazing stories that will uplift and inspire you.  As you learn about the people and communities that you help, we imagine that you will experience a sense of gratitude knowing that you played a role in their progress.  

We will produce results but there will be setbacks and evolutions so if you enjoy reading or watching underdog stories, this opportunity is for you. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Let our promotions business meet your company's promotional needs- it will help fund Africa Thryves effort.  

Regardless of your ability to contribute, please share our story with your friends and family!

story:
More than 2 billion people in the world today need glasses but don’t have them. 100 million of these people are school-aged children who cannot read the blackboard in class.

The problem is that they do not have access to an eye care professional or special equipment to find their prescription. This is one of the largest unaddressed health problems in the world today.

But we have a solution.

We use glasses with lenses that change shape so that the wearer can adjust the power of each lens until he or she can see clearly.

The Problem

Billions of people around the world suffer from poor vision as a result of uncorrected refractive error, which limits their ability to live a normal and productive life. In rich countries refractive error is readily corrected by eyeglasses, but in developing countries eyeglasses are primarily a luxury product available in urban areas.

The problem of poor vision is particularly important in school children, who have great difficulty learning at school. This has an untold impact on their education, their social participation, their overall quality of life, and ultimately their economic potential as individuals, and that of their communities.

Scale

There are over 100 million young people (age 12-18) in the developing world who suffer from myopia, or nearsightedness. 

Causes

We believe that there are five underlying reasons why young people do not have access to eyeglasses – awareness, access, affordability, attractiveness, and accuracy.

  • Awareness - Many living in poor villages are unaware either that they suffer from poor vision, or that poor vision can be corrected
  • Access - Eyeglasses are primarily available in urban optical shops; they are only rarely available in rural areas
  • Affordability - The total cost of obtaining corrective eyeglasses is too high – including time lost to work in travelling to multiple screening and fitting appointments
  • Attractiveness - Aesthetics are very important, particularly among teenagers, and eyeglasses can be a point of difference that leads to a social stigma. Cultural attitudes toward glasses, a belief that eyeglasses can be harmful, and comfort are other important factors
  • Accuracy - A significant proportion of people wearing eyeglasses in developing countries have inadequate correction that leaves them with poor visual acuity. This may be due to poor testing by an untrained person, or indeed a complete lack of professional testing.

Impact

The impact of poor vision on the educational, quality of life and economic potential of young people is substantial, but has not been well investigated. A recent working paper from the University of Minnesota based on schoolchildren in rural China estimates that wearing eyeglasses for a year increased average test scores by an amount equivalent to 0.33-0.5 extra years of schooling. This implies that poor vision presents a major problem to learning for these children.

The Solution 

New Self-Adjustable Glasses

The Centre for Vision in the Developing World developed self-adjustable glasses which the wearer can adjust until they see clearly. These glasses are based on a fluid-filled lens technology that is similar to that used in the Adspecs, the original self-adjustable, fluid-filled glasses developed by Professor Joshua Silver.

While the Adspecs were designed for use by adults, the Child Vision glasses have been developed specifically for use by young people aged from 12-18. These glasses are small, light and attractive, and have been designed to withstand hard use in challenging environments. They have also been designed to enable mass-manufacturing to keep the cost of production as low as possible.

Self-refraction is a scalable, sustainable solution to deliver high quality vision correction at low cost.

Perhaps the most important question is: do they work? Yes. Several recently published clinical trials prove this and can be read here, here and here. 

Pilot batches of glasses were deployed in schools in developing world countries in order to test distribution models.

The new glasses correct for myopia between 0 and -5D and will be available in various different colours.

This is where we need your help and support.

We need to raise as much money as possible to develop the Child Vision self-adjustable glasses for mass production and to distribute as many pairs of these glasses to children in schools in Africa, Asia & Latin America. We have an estimated delivery date, at the latest, for December 2017 if we start now.

Help us reach our goal by;

  • Supporting us through any of the perks.
  • Share our campaign on social media via the Indiegogo sharing tools above. Use the hashtag #HelpThemSee
  • Tell your friends about us.

 

How do you use self-adjustable glasses?

Self-adjustable glasses are designed for use in parts of the world where there are too few optometrists to meet the needs of the people. Self-adjustable glasses allow the wearer to adjust the lenses until he or she can see clearly. They are simple to adjust and will be delivered through schools.

Step 1: Check for poor vision

Perform a basic screening test for poor distance vision using the 'tumbling-E' illiterate vision chart.

Step 2: Adjust lenses

Turn the dials slowly on the side-arms until each eye can see clearly.

Step 3: Seal lenses

Press the buttons on the frame to seal the lenses in place, detach the adjuster tubes and prevent further adjustment.

Step 4: Remove adjusters

Unclip the adjusters from the side-arms and dispose of them safely. The glasses are now set and sealed and function like normal spectacles.

Step 5: Wear

Your Child Vision Adjustable Glasses are ready for use.

 

 

The Team

 Joshua Silver

Joshua Silver is an atomic physicist and Professor of Physics at the University of Oxford. He became interested in the emerging area of adaptive optics in the mid-1980s. After considering the way our eye-brain adaptive optical system works, he suggested that self-refraction with suitable adaptive lens eyeglasses could be a useful procedure for correcting refractive error, after trying such a procedure on himself. He created several prototypes of adaptive spectacles - including the Adspecs, the world's first fluid-filled universal eyeglasses - and he carried out research supported by the UK's DFID which showed that self-refraction with such glasses was a useful procedure for bringing vision correction to around half of the world's population which currently needs, but does not have, corrective eyewear. The self-refraction procedure is particularly useful for populations where there are too few eyecare professionals to meet the needs of the people. Josh hopes to see a billion people having vision correction by the year 2020.

 Chris Wray

Chris studied physics and philosophy at the University of Oxford before pursuing an entrepreneurial career, co-founding or advising new ventures in fields including online marketing and social media, cognitive models for organisational development, and adjustable-focus eyewear. Chris later studied law and was called to the Bar of England and Wales, and he continues to practise as a mediator in commercial and other civil disputes. Chris has worked with Professor Silver for more than ten years. He advised on all aspects of setting up the Centre for Vision in the Developing World.

Lawrence Jenkin

With over 40 years of design and production of spectacle frames experience, Lawrence makes made-to-measure frames for opticians, and the world of television and film. Lawrence has consulted on the adaptive eyewear project since its inception.

 Charlie Ingham

Charlie founded her own craft-focused British bespoke eyewear label in 2014, named SohoBespoke. She was brought on to work on the Child Vision crowdfunding campaign in November 2016.

 

Please note: If our goal is not attained we will send as many glasses to as many developing countries as we can for the sum we have raised.

More than 2 billion people in the world today need glasses but don’t have them. 100 million of these people are school-aged children who cannot read the blackboard in class.The problem is that they do not have access to an eye care professional or special equipment to find their prescription. This is one of the largest unaddressed health problems in the world today.But we have a solution.We use glasses with lenses that change shape so that the wearer can adjust the power of each lens until he or she can see clearly.The ProblemBillions of people around the world suffer from poor vision as a result of uncorrected refractive error, which limits their ability to live a normal and productive life. In rich countries refractive error is readily corrected by eyeglasses, but in developing countries eyeglasses are primarily a luxury product available in urban areas.The problem of poor vision is particularly important in school children, who have great difficulty learning at school. This has an untold impact on their education, their social participation, their overall quality of life, and ultimately their economic potential as individuals, and that of their communities.ScaleThere are over 100 million young people (age 12-18) in the developing world who suffer from myopia, or nearsightedness. CausesWe believe that there are five underlying reasons why young people do not have access to eyeglasses – awareness, access, affordability, attractiveness, and accuracy.

Awareness - Many living in poor villages are unaware either that they suffer from poor vision, or that poor vision can be corrected

Access - Eyeglasses are primarily available in urban optical shops; they are only rarely available in rural areas

Affordability - The total cost of obtaining corrective eyeglasses is too high – including time lost to work in travelling to multiple screening and fitting appointments

Attractiveness - Aesthetics are very important, particularly among teenagers, and eyeglasses can be a point of difference that leads to a social stigma. Cultural attitudes toward glasses, a belief that eyeglasses can be harmful, and comfort are other important factors

Accuracy - A significant proportion of people wearing eyeglasses in developing countries have inadequate correction that leaves them with poor visual acuity. This may be due to poor testing by an untrained person, or indeed a complete lack of professional testing.
ImpactThe impact of poor vision on the educational, quality of life and economic potential of young people is substantial, but has not been well investigated. A recent working paper from the University of Minnesota based on schoolchildren in rural China estimates that wearing eyeglasses for a year increased average test scores by an amount equivalent to 0.33-0.5 extra years of schooling. This implies that poor vision presents a major problem to learning for these children.The Solution New Self-Adjustable GlassesThe Centre for Vision in the Developing World developed self-adjustable glasses which the wearer can adjust until they see clearly. These glasses are based on a fluid-filled lens technology that is similar to that used in the Adspecs, the original self-adjustable, fluid-filled glasses developed by Professor Joshua Silver.While the Adspecs were designed for use by adults, the Child Vision glasses have been developed specifically for use by young people aged from 12-18. These glasses are small, light and attractive, and have been designed to withstand hard use in challenging environments. They have also been designed to enable mass-manufacturing to keep the cost of production as low as possible.Self-refraction is a scalable, sustainable solution to deliver high quality vision correction at low cost.Perhaps the most important question is: do they work? Yes. Several recently published clinical trials prove this and can be read here, here and here. Pilot batches of glasses were deployed in schools in developing world countries in order to test distribution models.The new glasses correct for myopia between 0 and -5D and will be available in various different colours.This is where we need your help and support.We need to raise as much money as possible to develop the Child Vision self-adjustable glasses for mass production and to distribute as many pairs of these glasses to children in schools in Africa, Asia & Latin America. We have an estimated delivery date, at the latest, for December 2017 if we start now.Help us reach our goal by;
Supporting us through any of the perks.
Share our campaign on social media via the Indiegogo sharing tools above. Use the hashtag #HelpThemSee
Tell your friends about us.
 How do you use self-adjustable glasses?Self-adjustable glasses are designed for use in parts of the world where there are too few optometrists to meet the needs of the people. Self-adjustable glasses allow the wearer to adjust the lenses until he or she can see clearly. They are simple to adjust and will be delivered through schools.Step 1: Check for poor visionPerform a basic screening test for poor distance vision using the 'tumbling-E' illiterate vision chart.Step 2: Adjust lensesTurn the dials slowly on the side-arms until each eye can see clearly.Step 3: Seal lensesPress the buttons on the frame to seal the lenses in place, detach the adjuster tubes and prevent further adjustment.Step 4: Remove adjustersUnclip the adjusters from the side-arms and dispose of them safely. The glasses are now set and sealed and function like normal spectacles.Step 5: WearYour Child Vision Adjustable Glasses are ready for use.  The Team Joshua SilverJoshua Silver is an atomic physicist and Professor of Physics at the University of Oxford. He became interested in the emerging area of adaptive optics in the mid-1980s. After considering the way our eye-brain adaptive optical system works, he suggested that self-refraction with suitable adaptive lens eyeglasses could be a useful procedure for correcting refractive error, after trying such a procedure on himself. He created several prototypes of adaptive spectacles - including the Adspecs, the world's first fluid-filled universal eyeglasses - and he carried out research supported by the UK's DFID which showed that self-refraction with such glasses was a useful procedure for bringing vision correction to around half of the world's population which currently needs, but does not have, corrective eyewear. The self-refraction procedure is particularly useful for populations where there are too few eyecare professionals to meet the needs of the people. Josh hopes to see a billion people having vision correction by the year 2020. Chris WrayChris studied physics and philosophy at the University of Oxford before pursuing an entrepreneurial career, co-founding or advising new ventures in fields including online marketing and social media, cognitive models for organisational development, and adjustable-focus eyewear. Chris later studied law and was called to the Bar of England and Wales, and he continues to practise as a mediator in commercial and other civil disputes. Chris has worked with Professor Silver for more than ten years. He advised on all aspects of setting up the Centre for Vision in the Developing World.Lawrence JenkinWith over 40 years of design and production of spectacle frames experience, Lawrence makes made-to-measure frames for opticians, and the world of television and film. Lawrence has consulted on the adaptive eyewear project since its inception. Charlie InghamCharlie founded her own craft-focused British bespoke eyewear label in 2014, named SohoBespoke. She was brought on to work on the Child Vision crowdfunding campaign in November 2016. Please note: If our goal is not attained we will send as many glasses to as many developing countries as we can for the sum we have raised.

story:
Creemos en el poder de la música. 

Hemos constatado las fibras que la música puede mover en los bebés y en los niños de edad preescolar. 

Las mamás que han probado nuestro método lo han considerado ideal para que sus bebés a través de la música, expandan su vocabulario y aprendan de una forma divertida a imitar, interactuar, socializar, resolver problemas, coordinar, entre otras habilidades cognoscitivas. 

En puerta se encuentra el material discográfico que respalda nuestro método. Ha superado nuestras expectativas y su sonido es sin duda superior a lo que se ha escuchado en nuestros salones de clase. 

Queremos que todos puedan escuchar a Ana & Gio en vivo y llevar a cabo nuestras clases a gran escala en foros abiertos a todo público. No serán simplemente conciertos sino experiencias únicas de aprendizaje para bebés y sus padres a través de la música. 

Creamos esta campaña para recabar la cantidad necesaria para cubrir los costos del material nuevo que acompañe nuestras canciones y que nos permita llegar a más niños y a sus padres. 

Tus contribuciones nos ayudarán a que nuestras clases de música se conviertan en un musical lleno de aprendizajes para las familias. 

Conoce más de nosotros en www.anaygio.com
