story:
Summary

Morgan O'Hara is a visual artist based in New York City. In January 2017, a time of stark political change in the United States, O'Hara felt the need to do something connected to her art practice which also addressed her political concerns and offered a sense of empowerment and encouragement to the community. Her practice of hand copying the Constitution of the United States - a document that is meant to protect the basic human rights of all American people - provided focus. Through hand copying, the writer absorbs information experientially, making room for reflection, new realizations, and an embodied understanding of the text. When done as a community, a sense of collaboration surfaces and nourishes.

HANDWRITING THE CONSTITUTION is not about learning by rote, but participation through writing. It is not about efficiency, but about taking time to contemplate meaning through the simple act of handwriting. As the writing flows, each person's gestures and choices give new form to the text, aligning the project with an art practice. It is also a social practice, a gathering in a public place for a collective effort. This project exists so people can know their rights, and resist negative thinking.

This project is not only intended for people in the United States. The Universal Declaration of Human Rights was hand copied in an O'Hara exhibition in Taipei, Taiwan in April and May of 2017, and she will hand write The Magna Carta in Dublin, Ireland in 2018. It is the intention of this project to involve as many people as possible to discover and handwrite documents that protect the basic human rights of all people. 

 

What We Need & What You Get

We are looking to fundraise $30,000 for:

- rental of space in which to work

- website hosting

- designer's work on the website www.handwritingtheconstitution.com

- website maintenance

- documentation of handwriting sessions (photo and video)

- outreach, daily correspondence, and collecting feedback from collaborators

- generation of national and international visibility, including writing press releases, interviews, and social media 

Up to this point, we have volunteered time and skills, such as video and photo documentation, the design of invitations to handwriting sessions, gathering materials for sessions, researching human rights documents, and organizing handwriting sessions. We'd like to continue these efforts in order to bring this project to as many people as possible and, of course, the rent must be paid.

If we do not reach our entire goal, we will continue to the best of our ability. At its most basic, a handwriting session is simple and inexpensive: a few copies of the document being handwritten, paper, pens, and a group of people who decide to give their time to experience an important document. The time consuming aspect of the project is administrative. 

 

Perks

$25 Donor name listed on website 

$50 Handwritten personalized thank you from O’Hara and the New York HANDWRITERS plus donor name listed on website

$100 Set of 5 different WE THE PEOPLE postcards plus donor name listed on website

$250 Have your name added to a document WE THE PEOPLE HANDWRITING THE CONSTITUTION done in the calligraphic style of the U.S. Constitution by O’Hara and posted on the website

$1000  Dinner in New York with two members of the HANDWRITING THE CONSTITUTION team

$2500 A member of the HANDWRITING THE CONSTITUTION team will go to your town and organize a handwriting session in your place of choice

$5000 Morgan will go to your town, give a lecture on the project, and organize a handwriting session in your place of choice

$30,000 Own a complete original handwritten copy of the Constitution done by Morgan O'Hara, approximately 10 handwritten pages on handmade paper.

 

The Impact

The process of HANDWRITING THE CONSTITUTION is transformative. It generates calm in the face of a daily bombardment from the news channels and social media. Clarity and peace of mind are essential to rational thought and decisive action and this process has been very useful in this regard. If you look at the website we created www.handwritingtheconstitution.com under COLLABORATOR STATEMENTS you will get an idea of the impact the process has had on other individuals. What kind of impact will it have on you? There is only one way to find out.

 

Risks & Challenges

The biggest risk or obstacle is that the project will diminish in scope rather than grow, simply because of limited resources for covering rent and professional services. Eventually it could turn back into one person at a table HANDWRITING THE CONSTITUTION as a solo activity. That wouldn't be bad, but it would be much better if the process and inspiration the practice generates would spread and more people would participate. The more cognizant we are of our rights as citizens, the more prepared we will be to recognize and act if these rights are threatened. If many of us are aware, the atmosphere can only improve.

We did not anticipate that putting HANDWRITING THE CONSTITUTION together would create such national enthusiasm. It was recently featured in the New York Times, the Primo Levi Institute, Art Net, and The New York Observer. Letters and emails arrive daily describing collaborators initiating their own handwriting sessions across the country. It is of course, wonderful that the idea generates interest and a desire to participate, but the time it takes to manage all of this and to make it grow is considerable. It has become a full time commitment and we still need to pay living expenses, rent, and professional services to keep it going. 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

1. Organize a HANDWRITING THE CONSTITUTION session in your town and send a few good images to handwritingtheconstitution@gmail.com

2. Write a few paragraphs about your take on the value of HANDWRITING THE CONSTITUTION

3. Get your local newspaper to post an article about the project

4. Use Indiegogo tools to promote the project

 

Thank you for becoming a part of the project and considering a donation.

- Morgan O'Hara and the Constitution Handwriters

story:
Imagine going to the theatre, but instead of a play, or an orchestra, you experience the Broadway of Science!

‘Give me a place to stand and with a lever, I will move the whole world.’ Archimedes.

Well maybe not the world yet, but surely a CAR seems impossible for children to lift! Enter the giant LEVER! Kids come onto the stage and experience the magic of science first hand!

Pic: Reference from the net.

 

INTRODUCING Deepak's FABLABSHOW, with PRATEEK and CHYP

FABLABSHOW is a Theatre scale, Live Fun Science Stage Show series that will travel across the country! It is one and a half hours of exciting content, dramatic presentation, laughs and fun with completely experiential science. We want to inculcate not just the study of science, but a LOVE for it!

Scale and Drama meet FUN SCIENCE! The presentations and exhibits will become memorable experiences which also help understand principles in science. The joys of experiencing Science at work will take education to a different level through examples of things can be done with the science that they learn at school.

So one might say,

‘Each school has a science lab, so why do we need to come to see a science show?’ or

‘Science Education is the number 1 focussed-on subject in the country, so why one more format?

Well, that’s exactly WHY!

Yes, we have labs in schools and YES, science education is highly focussed on, but can these replicate the passion or the love for science? According to a PISA Report, in 2009, which evaluates ‘what 15-year-olds know, and what they can DO with what they know’, Indian students ranked 72nd among the 73 countries that participated.

Granted that some changes have happened from there on, but not enough.

We want a chance to do just that, help children to realise that science doesn't just have to be "studied" it can also be DONE and then it IS a lot of Fun. We just aim to make it memorable by taking the scale of presentation to a level that schools and workshop providers do no reach. This makes the experience memorable too.

Lofty Goals? Yes!

Daunting task? Yes!

Loads of Fun? YES!

Years of research, experimentations and our successful YouTube channel later we finally have a live science show format that will be taken across the country.

 

WHO WE ARE:

Hi, I'm Deepak Pathania, an Industrial Designer (National Institute of Design, Ahmedabad, India) and entrepreneur but more importantly, I'm a compulsive maker/inventor. 

I have more than 2 decades of experience in Design while successfully running my extremely multidisciplinary design company www.designintervention.biz . In 2009 we got a chance to create content for a science tv show called F.A.Q for Turner Network's POGO channel. Eventually, from 2009-2013, our team developed close to 1000 experiments for 3 TV shows (100 episodes worth) and it became clear, THIS is what I what I LOVE doing, to create products and large-scale presentations and share the excitement with everyone.

Interestingly, India sees a lot of clever ideas coming from within, but with zero attention to the presentation/aesthetics. So there was a niche for international-standard content, especially in the Indian Fun-Science online domain, and we decided to throw our hat in the ring.  I gave up the full-time design work and totally pivoted my career to start this ambitious Fun-Science journey.

 

d'Art of Science

 

www.youtube.com/dartofscience  was started in 2014. Using our TV content experience we create videos with innovative content and production standards at par with the best in the world; a point highlighted when d'Art of Science was listed among the "Top 100 Science Youtube Channels on the planet"  by Feedspot.com (the only ones from India).

Releasing one video every Friday, we now have more than 200 experiment/presentation episodes online.

People do tell us that our videos are really exciting and informative, kids love it and parents watch it too. Most kids write back saying they got inspired and are doing some hands-on experiments and some even won prizes in school after following some of the DIYs.  The best compliments from parents are "I wish this existed when I was growing up". The videos are structured so that they are not only useful for kids or science enthusiasts but can be used as an effective teaching tool for DIY projects in schools and social help organisations.

 

FABLABSHOW

Well, the natural progression from this was doing live shows since we were getting a lot of demand from institutions as well as schools and families to do live engagements! We decided to do that, but then like in all things that we endeavour, we are dreaming of this bigger experience that we want to share.

Hence, we looked at the best shows across the world, not just based on science, but across entertainment and we came up with our very own SteamPunk themed Science Show!

 

That's what we want to do

Create a one and half hour live science stage production that will grow to rival the best Broadway shows in terms of scale and excitement.

That’s not all, we want to make it such that it can travel and can be taken from stage to stage in different cities and towns across the country and make it accessible and affordable to everyone.

The presentations and exhibits will become memorable experiences which also help understand principles in science. The joys of experiencing Science at work will take education to a different level through examples of things can be done with the science that they learn at school.

We want to inculcate not just the study of science, but a LOVE for doing Science!

Show Structure and Content:

Each show will be divided into 4 quarters of roughly 15 minutes, wherein each we will take 1 or 2 science principles/topics and show some exciting small experiments to start it off and then progressively scale it up like we did for the TV shows. In the video you can see how we had scaled up a simple topic like friction where we started with a wooden stick on a drill machine creating friction to start a fire, to a stick picking up a bottle of rice, to interleaving books to facilitate a tug of war, to eventually lifting a whole car using telephone directories interleaved for friction. We cant get a car and a crane on stage, but we will create a platform just about 3 inches from the ground on which we will see how many kids does it take to break the bond. And this is just one of the many exciting examples of things we have planned. The excitement of seeing larger than life is obvious even on screen, but now it will be multiplied by seeing it LIVE on Stage. These will create amazing memories for a lifetime. This is going to be exciting and we hope that more and more kids and even teachers will get inspired to DO science that's taught in school.

Host:

Prateek Dhruva is a quirky nerdy guy! He has been presenting for about 10 years now. With over a 100 live shows under his belt, he has presented children's events, quizzes, game shows and workshops for children across age groups. He has helped conceptulise, develop and execute numerous properties for live events, educational products, digital shows and television. Being a natural storyteller and his passion for science and science education makes him a perfect fit for FabLabShow.

And did we mention

That besides our fabulous Live host, Prateek, we will have a ROBOT host too?

INTRODUCING CHYP - Computerised HYbrid Personoid

 

 

 

Because every great show needs an awesome ROBOT!

 

WHAT WE NEED:

Target Amount: INR ₹18,00,000/- (USD 28,350$)
Cost Average @ INR ₹1,50,000/- per show (USD 2370) if we do around 2 shows (booking the hall for one full day) in each of the 6 cities totaling 12 shows (cost includes halls, sound, light, team, travel, boarding lodging, material transport by truck, temporary warehouse spaces, taxes, commissions/deductions etc)

If we get funded beyond these targets then we will simply use the additional money to reach out to more cities and towns and do that many more shows. 

If we get funded lower than the target, even then we will use the money to reach out to as many children as we can and as the amounts enable.

Note:

We are keeping the perks or Rewards of your contributions simple. You could either donate a small or big amount without any strings except a thank you shoutout on a video on youtube as well as before these 24 shows in the hall. 

Or,  You could choose to donate $15 onwards going up to any amount. For each $15, we will assign one show pass that will entitle one kid from an NGO or a Govt School to experience the show. 50% of the audience capacity of each show that we do will be blocked for these Kids. Therefore this should take care of the costs of the show and will help to make this ambitious project happen. The other 50% seats will be ticketed so that we make profits to help create more content in a continuous cycle. In the first year we hope to do a few shows in most metros and later we could take it to smaller towns and cities too. 

So this is how it goes. You could be from Bangalore (or any other city/state), now living anywhere in the world and you decide you want to gift this experience to 1 or 10 or 100 or 1000 kids from Bangalore/Karnataka (or your city/state). You donate accordingly and let us know the city you want the gift for. We are partnering with DFC India for this because they have a huge network of schools for their competitions. We will give the relevant number of passes to DFC India for your chosen city and DFC will hand it out to their network of schools in the region. This makes it all clear and transparent.

The disbursement of tickets to the deserving* children will be done through our partner, Design for Change. You can find out about DFC at www.dfcworld.com

*Deserving: Not only just underprivileged kids but even a handful of deserving kids who have shown keen interest and an aptitude of doing science and these lists would be extracted from entries of DFC over the years.

The Goa tickets will be exclusively given to the Science Film Festival of India ( http://sciffigoa.org ) as our Goa Partners.

 

Process

The Process of creating the content has been going on for a year and the consciousness of the same has been on for many years. Rituja is a kids curriculum writer as well as helps develop curriculum for alternate education as well. She along with Prateek and Deepak have been working on this to bring it to this stage.

The prototyping of all the structures required has been done for testing and the final pieces are being made currently.

Chyp is being made currently and for the kids, Chyp will be an autonomous robot as we also aim for eventually, but in reality we will have a person manning it to begin to see what kind of interactions are required in the show as it evolves, because, in front of different kinds of audiences, different adaptations might be required which is difficult in programming. However, we do hope to either evolve Chyp into an AI-based robot over the years, or if we get a tech sponsor/partner for Chyp, we can do that faster. For the Kids, Chyp will be a robot, the same way they feel "Crash" in F.A.Q on Pogo is a robot (Deepak had helped the show become a reality from its pilot stage)

We will script the entire show and create a program flow to make sure we are covering things from the curriculum, in a grand and safe way.

We start rehearsals and creating our final stage backdrops in January 2018 and take a whole lot of photos and videos to make sure we are doing it right, it looks great and leak a few online, so that we can start creating buzz!

We aim to test launch the complete show in February in Margao in Goa where the D'art of Science team is based

Depending on the funding amount, we will continuously plan out and book halls in the mentioned cities. We will keep maintaining a list of cities that people are funding against (it will be made clear by mail or other mechanisms that Indiegogo allows) and will intimate DFC about it by sharing all the dashboard information with them. The tickets for the State of Goa will be given to our Partner SCI-FFI (Science Film Festival of India).

We would love to have people join us for Social Media Marketing, Scriptwriting and most importantly Theatrical tips.
story_txt: Imagine going to the theatre, but instead of a play, or an orchestra, you experience the Broadway of Science!‘Give me a place to stand and with a lever, I will move the whole world.’ Archimedes.Well maybe not the world yet, but surely a CAR seems impossible for children to lift! Enter the giant LEVER! Kids come onto the stage and experience the magic of science first hand!Pic: Reference from the net. INTRODUCING Deepak's FABLABSHOW, with PRATEEK and CHYPFABLABSHOW is a Theatre scale, Live Fun Science Stage Show series that will travel across the country! It is one and a half hours of exciting content, dramatic presentation, laughs and fun with completely experiential science. We want to inculcate not just the study of science, but a LOVE for it!Scale and Drama meet FUN SCIENCE! The presentations and exhibits will become memorable experiences which also help understand principles in science. The joys of experiencing Science at work will take education to a different level through examples of things can be done with the science that they learn at school.So one might say,‘Each school has a science lab, so why do we need to come to see a science show?’ or‘Science Education is the number 1 focussed-on subject in the country, so why one more format?Well, that’s exactly WHY!Yes, we have labs in schools and YES, science education is highly focussed on, but can these replicate the passion or the love for science? According to a PISA Report, in 2009, which evaluates ‘what 15-year-olds know, and what they can DO with what they know’, Indian students ranked 72nd among the 73 countries that participated.Granted that some changes have happened from there on, but not enough.We want a chance to do just that, help children to realise that science doesn't just have to be "studied" it can also be DONE and then it IS a lot of Fun. We just aim to make it memorable by taking the scale of presentation to a level that schools and workshop providers do no reach. This makes the experience memorable too.Lofty Goals? Yes!Daunting task? Yes!Loads of Fun? YES!Years of research, experimentations and our successful YouTube channel later we finally have a live science show format that will be taken across the country. WHO WE ARE:Hi, I'm Deepak Pathania, an Industrial Designer (National Institute of Design, Ahmedabad, India) and entrepreneur but more importantly, I'm a compulsive maker/inventor. I have more than 2 decades of experience in Design while successfully running my extremely multidisciplinary design company www.designintervention.biz . In 2009 we got a chance to create content for a science tv show called F.A.Q for Turner Network's POGO channel. Eventually, from 2009-2013, our team developed close to 1000 experiments for 3 TV shows (100 episodes worth) and it became clear, THIS is what I what I LOVE doing, to create products and large-scale presentations and share the excitement with everyone.Interestingly, India sees a lot of clever ideas coming from within, but with zero attention to the presentation/aesthetics. So there was a niche for international-standard content, especially in the Indian Fun-Science online domain, and we decided to throw our hat in the ring.  I gave up the full-time design work and totally pivoted my career to start this ambitious Fun-Science journey. d'Art of Science www.youtube.com/dartofscience  was started in 2014. Using our TV content experience we create videos with innovative content and production standards at par with the best in the world; a point highlighted when d'Art of Science was listed among the "Top 100 Science Youtube Channels on the planet"  by Feedspot.com (the only ones from India).Releasing one video every Friday, we now have more than 200 experiment/presentation episodes online.People do tell us that our videos are really exciting and informative, kids love it and parents watch it too. Most kids write back saying they got inspired and are doing some hands-on experiments and some even won prizes in school after following some of the DIYs.  The best compliments from parents are "I wish this existed when I was growing up". The videos are structured so that they are not only useful for kids or science enthusiasts but can be used as an effective teaching tool for DIY projects in schools and social help organisations. FABLABSHOWWell, the natural progression from this was doing live shows since we were getting a lot of demand from institutions as well as schools and families to do live engagements! We decided to do that, but then like in all things that we endeavour, we are dreaming of this bigger experience that we want to share.Hence, we looked at the best shows across the world, not just based on science, but across entertainment and we came up with our very own SteamPunk themed Science Show! That's what we want to doCreate a one and half hour live science stage production that will grow to rival the best Broadway shows in terms of scale and excitement.That’s not all, we want to make it such that it can travel and can be taken from stage to stage in different cities and towns across the country and make it accessible and affordable to everyone.The presentations and exhibits will become memorable experiences which also help understand principles in science. The joys of experiencing Science at work will take education to a different level through examples of things can be done with the science that they learn at school.We want to inculcate not just the study of science, but a LOVE for doing Science!Show Structure and Content:Each show will be divided into 4 quarters of roughly 15 minutes, wherein each we will take 1 or 2 science principles/topics and show some exciting small experiments to start it off and then progressively scale it up like we did for the TV shows. In the video you can see how we had scaled up a simple topic like friction where we started with a wooden stick on a drill machine creating friction to start a fire, to a stick picking up a bottle of rice, to interleaving books to facilitate a tug of war, to eventually lifting a whole car using telephone directories interleaved for friction. We cant get a car and a crane on stage, but we will create a platform just about 3 inches from the ground on which we will see how many kids does it take to break the bond. And this is just one of the many exciting examples of things we have planned. The excitement of seeing larger than life is obvious even on screen, but now it will be multiplied by seeing it LIVE on Stage. These will create amazing memories for a lifetime. This is going to be exciting and we hope that more and more kids and even teachers will get inspired to DO science that's taught in school.Host:Prateek Dhruva is a quirky nerdy guy! He has been presenting for about 10 years now. With over a 100 live shows under his belt, he has presented children's events, quizzes, game shows and workshops for children across age groups. He has helped conceptulise, develop and execute numerous properties for live events, educational products, digital shows and television. Being a natural storyteller and his passion for science and science education makes him a perfect fit for FabLabShow.And did we mentionThat besides our fabulous Live host, Prateek, we will have a ROBOT host too?INTRODUCING CHYP - Computerised HYbrid Personoid   Because every great show needs an awesome ROBOT! WHAT WE NEED:Target Amount: INR ₹18,00,000/- (USD 28,350$)Cost Average @ INR ₹1,50,000/- per show (USD 2370) if we do around 2 shows (booking the hall for one full day) in each of the 6 cities totaling 12 shows (cost includes halls, sound, light, team, travel, boarding lodging, material transport by truck, temporary warehouse spaces, taxes, commissions/deductions etc)If we get funded beyond these targets then we will simply use the additional money to reach out to more cities and towns and do that many more shows. If we get funded lower than the target, even then we will use the money to reach out to as many children as we can and as the amounts enable.Note: We are keeping the perks or Rewards of your contributions simple. You could either donate a small or big amount without any strings except a thank you shoutout on a video on youtube as well as before these 24 shows in the hall. Or,  You could choose to donate $15 onwards going up to any amount. For each $15, we will assign one show pass that will entitle one kid from an NGO or a Govt School to experience the show. 50% of the audience capacity of each show that we do will be blocked for these Kids. Therefore this should take care of the costs of the show and will help to make this ambitious project happen. The other 50% seats will be ticketed so that we make profits to help create more content in a continuous cycle. In the first year we hope to do a few shows in most metros and later we could take it to smaller towns and cities too. So this is how it goes. You could be from Bangalore (or any other city/state), now living anywhere in the world and you decide you want to gift this experience to 1 or 10 or 100 or 1000 kids from Bangalore/Karnataka (or your city/state). You donate accordingly and let us know the city you want the gift for. We are partnering with DFC India for this because they have a huge network of schools for their competitions. We will give the relevant number of passes to DFC India for your chosen city and DFC will hand it out to their network of schools in the region. This makes it all clear and transparent.The disbursement of tickets to the deserving* children will be done through our partner, Design for Change. You can find out about DFC at www.dfcworld.com*Deserving: Not only just underprivileged kids but even a handful of deserving kids who have shown keen interest and an aptitude of doing science and these lists would be extracted from entries of DFC over the years.The Goa tickets will be exclusively given to the Science Film Festival of India ( http://sciffigoa.org ) as our Goa Partners. ProcessThe Process of creating the content has been going on for a year and the consciousness of the same has been on for many years. Rituja is a kids curriculum writer as well as helps develop curriculum for alternate education as well. She along with Prateek and Deepak have been working on this to bring it to this stage.The prototyping of all the structures required has been done for testing and the final pieces are being made currently.Chyp is being made currently and for the kids, Chyp will be an autonomous robot as we also aim for eventually, but in reality we will have a person manning it to begin to see what kind of interactions are required in the show as it evolves, because, in front of different kinds of audiences, different adaptations might be required which is difficult in programming. However, we do hope to either evolve Chyp into an AI-based robot over the years, or if we get a tech sponsor/partner for Chyp, we can do that faster. For the Kids, Chyp will be a robot, the same way they feel "Crash" in F.A.Q on Pogo is a robot (Deepak had helped the show become a reality from its pilot stage)We will script the entire show and create a program flow to make sure we are covering things from the curriculum, in a grand and safe way.We start rehearsals and creating our final stage backdrops in January 2018 and take a whole lot of photos and videos to make sure we are doing it right, it looks great and leak a few online, so that we can start creating buzz!We aim to test launch the complete show in February in Margao in Goa where the D'art of Science team is basedDepending on the funding amount, we will continuously plan out and book halls in the mentioned cities. We will keep maintaining a list of cities that people are funding against (it will be made clear by mail or other mechanisms that Indiegogo allows) and will intimate DFC about it by sharing all the dashboard information with them. The tickets for the State of Goa will be given to our Partner SCI-FFI (Science Film Festival of India).We would love to have people join us for Social Media Marketing, Scriptwriting and most importantly Theatrical tips.

story:
About Papua New Guinea

Papua New Guinea is a country of intense diversity. Besides being home to 5% of the world’s biodiversity, its 6.5 million people speak over 800 separate languages, about 12% of the world’s total.

This incredible diversity is not reflected in the schools. Papua New Guinea was an Australian colony until 1975 and its school system is still heavily influenced by Australian models. Schools teach in English and while an effort is made to teach topics common to all Papua New Guineans, the many distinct tribal and local cultures remain invisible at school. 

When you went to school, you probably read books about your own people, your own country, and your own culture. They were probably in the same language your parents, grandparents, and neighbours spoke. But when young Nalik children go to school, they see books in English, usually from another country, and talking about ways of life that are very different from their own. There are no books talking about the culture of their ancestors. 

A Maani: Birds and Nalik Culture is an attempt to address the imbalance and show that the local culture has an important place in the education of young Papua New Guineans. In 2016 linguist Dr Craig Alan Volker and social educator Cláudio da Silva traveled to Madina Village on New Ireland in the Bismarck Archipelago of Papua New Guinea to work with children, clan chiefs, and community leaders to collect stories and traditional knowledge about birds on New Ireland and how they represent the matrilineal clans of the Nalik-speaking people. The result was A Maani: Birds and Nalik Culture.

Collecting stories and writing a book

A Maani: Birds and Nalik Culture was written by grade 6 and 7 children at Madina Primary School in the Nalik region of New Ireland, an island in the Bismarck Archipelago in northeastern Papua New Guinea. Using stories from their parents, grandparents, clan matriarchs, and clan chiefs, they wrote about the birds in their local environment and what they mean to people there. Some stories were told by clan chiefs and female elders. Children listened to the stories, translated them into English, and drew pictures that eventually became part of the book. Children also asked their parents and grandparents for stories, legends, and information about birds. They worked in groups to retell these stories in English. We have gathered the stories and illustrations into a book: A Maani, Birds and Nalik Culture. This book will provide Nalik children a chance to read about their maani (birds) and share their culture with people everywhere.

Nalik culture is matrilineal, with society based on eight clans, with strict laws describing interactions between the clans. Nalik children need to learn these laws and customs to participate as adults in society, but with increasing westernisation, many no longer learn this ancient wisdom at home. A Maani: Birds and Nalik Culture is a book, but it was also a process of showing young adolescents how to learn about their ancestral culture and how to integrate that knowledge into what they learn at school. Now that the book is finished, it needs to be printed and distributed. You can help.

The book will be self-published, with 3000 copies distributed free of charge to schools in the Nalik and neighbouring northern New Ireland area, where the languages and cultures are closely related to the Nalik culture and language.

 

Cláudio da Silva is a biologist and educator. Originally from Brazil, he worked in environmental education there before moving to teach Japan for nine years. He recently completed a masters degree at the University of Coimbra in Portugal, where he now lives. For his thesis on the process of incorporating New Ireland culture into the government school system, he worked with community leaders to develop a project for school children to write about their own culture. The result was A Maani: Birds and Nalik Culture. 

Neil Gaalis is a maimai (chief) of the Moxokala (Red-Bellied Pita) Clan of the Nalik people of New Ireland. He is a farmer and has a strong interest in xulmu, the philosophical underpinnings of Nalik culture. His active participation ensures that Nalik cultural values and language are maintained and that A Maani: Birds and Nalik Culture expresses these values in a positive way. 

​Craig Alan Volker is a retired professor of linguistics at Gifu Shōtoku Gakuen University in Japan and Professor of Linguistic Research at Divine Word University in Papua New Guinea. Currently he is an adjunct professor at The Cairns Institute, James Cook University in Australia. Originally from the United States, he now spends part of every year in Madina Village, New Ireland, where he is a wangpaang (assistant talking chief) of the Moxomaraba (Sea Eagle) Clan. He produced the writing system for the previously unwritten Nalik language and edited the Oxford University Press Oxford  Papua New Guinea Dictionary of Tok Pisin. For this project, he translated some of the texts told by elders for A Maani: Birds and Nalik Culture and helped students express themselves more authentically in English. 

The team has already met in Papua New Guinea twice for this project, using their own funds for travel, recording equipment, and materials. We met with school and community leaders, and gathered stories about birds that clan matriarchs and chiefs thought were important. Then we held a two-month workshop with Madina Primary School grade 6 and 7 students, working with students to produce the book. Several copies of the book were printed at the team’s own cost so that the school, the students, and community leaders could approve its publication.

Now we are ready to print the book. To print and distribute 3000 copies of the book at no cost to schools in northern New Ireland, we need to raise US$ 38,300.

  • Printing and shipping US$ 30,000

This is where most of the funds will go. At a cost of US$10 per book, US-based Education Projects International will partner with Birdwing Books, a leading publisher of school textbooks and children’s books in Papua New Guinea, to arrange for 3000 books to be  printed in China and shipped to Port Moresby the capital of Papua New Guinea, before being airlifted on to New Ireland in the Bismarck Archipelago. 

  • Travel US$ 7500

Cláudio will fly from Portugal (US$4380 round trip) and Craig from Arizona, USA (US$3120 round trip) to oversee the distribution of the books together with Neil Gaalis, a Nalik maimai (clan chief) who oversaw cultural aspects of the project. 

  • Distribution US$ 500

Using local vehicles, and minibuses, 3000 books will be distributed free of charge to elementary, primary, and secondary schools in northern New Ireland. In addition, each child in the two classes of Madina Primary School who helped write the book will receive an individual copy. 

  • Opening ceremony US$300

In Papua New Guinea, all important projects are “launched” with traditional ceremonies involving dances and public presentations. At the launching of this book, the school children who wrote the book will present traditional dances and give copies of the book to the provincial governor and other local leaders. Neil Gaalis will organise the launching ceremony in a way that suits traditional Nalik culture. 

The Impact

The response to the book has already been very positive. For people who have never seen themselves reflected in books, the impact holding a book about their own stories and lives cannot be overestimated. Through the workshop that produced A Maani: Birds and Nalik Culture, students have seen how the skills they have learned at school actually do have real-life application. Teachers already report that they apply themselves more to classwork and to being more precise in their assignments.

The team hopes that this book and project will be a model for other communities to produce their own books in their own languages. 

Is this book culturally acceptable to Nalik people?

A maimai (clan chief), Neil Gaalis, was part of the team throughout the time we spent together in New Ireland. Because of this and, more importantly, because the book was produced with the aid of community leaders, and approved by them once it was finished, we know it is in line with Nalik cultural values and morality. This is a Nalik book with words and stories by Nalik people, produced by them with some help from two of their friends.

The production of the book was covered in The National Weekender, one of the most widely read newspapers in Papua New Guinea. You can click here to read about the article: http://www.thenational.com.pg/its-a-bird/

After thousands of people read the article, the project received national attention. This was a time when critical Nalik people could have complained about the project. None did. In fact, the reaction was so positive that Cláudio was interviewed for the provincial radio station to talk about the project and the importance of introducing indigenous knowledge into the school system.

What if we don’t reach our financial goal?

The team is committed to distributing these books to the fullest extent open to us. If we receive enough money to print only 10 books, at least 10 books will be printed and placed in schools. Ideally though, every school in the northern New Ireland area should get a class set.

How do we know that the book will actually be distributed?

The distribution will be reported in The National newspaper of PNG (www.thenational.com.og), which has been following our story since we first began. A list of the schools receiving books will be placed online, with videos of the opening ceremony and book distributions at schools placed online  And you are very welcome to come to New Ireland with us come and join us in distributing the books to see for yourself what kind of impact your support has given. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Can't give to our campaign? No problem! You can still help these children to receive a printed copy of “A Maani” Birds and Nalik Culture” book.
Using Indiegogo’s share buttons on the top of this page, share it on your Facebook, Tweet it and Email it to friends. The more people who know, the better our chances of reaching our goal!

story:
Due to the world economic crisis, CENIT is not receiving the same funding as it did previously from national and international donors, thus putting at risk our mission of helping children and adolescents of South, Quito. We truly need your help in order to continue supporting these vulnerable populations. Please read on below to learn more about CENIT, and consider making a donation. Thank you!

Debido a la crisis económica mundial, CENIT ya no cuenta con los mismos fondos que hemos recibido antes de donantes nacionales e internacionales, lo cual le pone en riesgo nuestra misión de ayudar a los niños, niñas, y adolescentes del sur de Quito. Realmente necesitamos su ayuda para seguir apoyando a estas poblaciones vulnerables. Por favor, infórmense sobre el trabajo de CENIT, y piense en hacer una donación. ¡Gracias!

¿Qué es? - What is it?

The Integral Center of Childhood and Adolescence is a non-profit, NGO with 25 years experience, directed by the Sisters of the Good Shepard. We develop, and have developed, various programs aimed towards the support of boys, girls, and adolescents who have fallen into situations of vulnerability, with the general goal of progressively eradicating child labor, protecting children's rights, promoting the equality of gender, and improving general living conditions.

El Centro Integral de la Niñez y Adolescencia, CENIT, es una organización sin fines de lucro con 25 años de experiencia, dirigida por la Congregación Religiosa del Buen Pastor. Desarrollamos estrategias y programas de atención integral para acoger a las niñas/os y adolescentes en situación de riesgo y vulnerabilidad, con el objetivo de erradicar el trabajo infantil, promover el ejercicio de derechos, equidad de género, vivencia de valores y mejorar sus condiciones de vida.

Misión - Mission:

Our mission is to create efficient integral educational programs, with a solid institutional structure that involves both private and public sectors, as well as national and international volunteers. Our work is based in three intersecting themes: children's rights, gender equality, and spirituality. All of our efforts are geared towards the eradication of child labor, and improving the quality of life of vulnerable children and adolescents and their families.

Nuestra misión es crear programas integrales educativos y productivos eficientes a largo plazo; con una estructura sólida en la organización que involucre al sector público y privado, voluntarios nacionales y extranjeros. Basados en tres ejes transversales: enfoque de derechos, equidad de genero, y espiritualidad. Todos estos recursos sincronizados y enfocados a erradicar el trabajo de NNAs, ofreciendo nuevas alternativas y mejorando sus condiciones de vida y las de su familia que se encuentran en situaciones vulnerables. 

Visión - Vision:

Our vision is to be an organization that supports children, adolescents and their families, positioned and recognized both nationally and internationally, offering integral support to said populations, and expanding its programs throughout Ecuador with the help of public and private institutions, as well as that of national and international volunteers who are competent, proactive, and involved,

Ser una organización de acogida a las niñas, los niños, adolescentes y sus familias, reconocida y posicionada a nivel nacional e internacional, precursora en la atención integral, expandiendo sus programas a nivel nacional con el apoyo de instituciones públicas y privadas con personal- voluntarios nacionales y extranjeros capacitados, proactivos e involucrados.

Programas - Programs:

MI FAMILIA

Offering formative opportunities for the parents of our students and program participants, including workshops on children's rights, parenting, gender equality, and spirituality. Additionally, we offer occupational training in hair styling, tailoring, jewelry making and micro-finance.   

Formación para padres en Derechos, Buen Trato, Equidad de Género, Espiritualidad y Talleres ocupacionales de Belleza, Corte-Confección, Tarjeteria, Bisutería, y formación microempresarial.

BIOSICOSOCIAL

Intervention and continued services in psychology, social work and health directed towards children, adolescents, and families. Our Biosicosocial team also helps to offer students and program participants a daily nutritious lunch. 

Intervención y seguimiento en psicología, trabajo social y salud a las niñas/os, adolescentes y familias. Atención diaria del comedor.

VOLUNTARIADO

CENIT receives and collaborates with Ecuadorian and international volunteers who work directly with Ecuadorian educators, social workers, and psychologists to support our various programs.

CENIT, recibe la colaboración de voluntarios ecuatorianos y extranjeros que brindan su apoyo integrándose de manera proactiva en las diferentes áreas y departamentos.

RESCATE DE CALLE

Offers support and educational opportunities to children and adolescents who find themselves in situations of vulnerability and/or child labor, most notably through our market preschool program. 

Abordaje de niñas/os y adolescentes en situación de trabajo infantil y/o vulnerabilidad.

CENTRO DE APOYO CEA

Homework help, tutoring, and recreational activities for child laborers and at-risk children who attend public schools in nearby neighborhoods.

Tareas dirigidas, refuerzo escolar y recreación para niñas, niños trabajadores o en situación de riesgo, que asisten a las Escuelas del sector aledaño a CENIT.

PRIMARIA “CENIT”

Basic primary school education in three years for children and adolescents who have fallen behind and/or dropped out of school, and/or who are in situations of vulnerability.

Educación Básica en 3 años para niñas, niños y adolescentes con rezago escolar y en situación de vulnerabilidad, que tengan 8 años de edad, en adelante.

CENTRO ARTESANAL “ROSA VIRGINIA”

Workshops and classes on various topics related to intestinal production, most notably sewing, jewelry design, and cooking, for adolescents and young people who have already completed the seventh grade.

Capacitación en ramas artesanales de Corte-Confección-Bordado y Ebanistería para Adolescentes y jóvenes de 15 años en adelante que han terminado el Séptimo Año de Básica.
story_txt: Due to the world economic crisis, CENIT is not receiving the same funding as it did previously from national and international donors, thus putting at risk our mission of helping children and adolescents of South, Quito. We truly need your help in order to continue supporting these vulnerable populations. Please read on below to learn more about CENIT, and consider making a donation. Thank you!Debido a la crisis económica mundial, CENIT ya no cuenta con los mismos fondos que hemos recibido antes de donantes nacionales e internacionales, lo cual le pone en riesgo nuestra misión de ayudar a los niños, niñas, y adolescentes del sur de Quito. Realmente necesitamos su ayuda para seguir apoyando a estas poblaciones vulnerables. Por favor, infórmense sobre el trabajo de CENIT, y piense en hacer una donación. ¡Gracias!¿Qué es? - What is it?The Integral Center of Childhood and Adolescence is a non-profit, NGO with 25 years experience, directed by the Sisters of the Good Shepard. We develop, and have developed, various programs aimed towards the support of boys, girls, and adolescents who have fallen into situations of vulnerability, with the general goal of progressively eradicating child labor, protecting children's rights, promoting the equality of gender, and improving general living conditions.El Centro Integral de la Niñez y Adolescencia, CENIT, es una organización sin fines de lucro con 25 años de experiencia, dirigida por la Congregación Religiosa del Buen Pastor. Desarrollamos estrategias y programas de atención integral para acoger a las niñas/os y adolescentes en situación de riesgo y vulnerabilidad, con el objetivo de erradicar el trabajo infantil, promover el ejercicio de derechos, equidad de género, vivencia de valores y mejorar sus condiciones de vida.Misión - Mission:Our mission is to create efficient integral educational programs, with a solid institutional structure that involves both private and public sectors, as well as national and international volunteers. Our work is based in three intersecting themes: children's rights, gender equality, and spirituality. All of our efforts are geared towards the eradication of child labor, and improving the quality of life of vulnerable children and adolescents and their families.Nuestra misión es crear programas integrales educativos y productivos eficientes a largo plazo; con una estructura sólida en la organización que involucre al sector público y privado, voluntarios nacionales y extranjeros. Basados en tres ejes transversales: enfoque de derechos, equidad de genero, y espiritualidad. Todos estos recursos sincronizados y enfocados a erradicar el trabajo de NNAs, ofreciendo nuevas alternativas y mejorando sus condiciones de vida y las de su familia que se encuentran en situaciones vulnerables. Visión - Vision:Our vision is to be an organization that supports children, adolescents and their families, positioned and recognized both nationally and internationally, offering integral support to said populations, and expanding its programs throughout Ecuador with the help of public and private institutions, as well as that of national and international volunteers who are competent, proactive, and involved,Ser una organización de acogida a las niñas, los niños, adolescentes y sus familias, reconocida y posicionada a nivel nacional e internacional, precursora en la atención integral, expandiendo sus programas a nivel nacional con el apoyo de instituciones públicas y privadas con personal- voluntarios nacionales y extranjeros capacitados, proactivos e involucrados.Programas - Programs:MI FAMILIAOffering formative opportunities for the parents of our students and program participants, including workshops on children's rights, parenting, gender equality, and spirituality. Additionally, we offer occupational training in hair styling, tailoring, jewelry making and micro-finance.   Formación para padres en Derechos, Buen Trato, Equidad de Género, Espiritualidad y Talleres ocupacionales de Belleza, Corte-Confección, Tarjeteria, Bisutería, y formación microempresarial.BIOSICOSOCIALIntervention and continued services in psychology, social work and health directed towards children, adolescents, and families. Our Biosicosocial team also helps to offer students and program participants a daily nutritious lunch. Intervención y seguimiento en psicología, trabajo social y salud a las niñas/os, adolescentes y familias. Atención diaria del comedor.VOLUNTARIADOCENIT receives and collaborates with Ecuadorian and international volunteers who work directly with Ecuadorian educators, social workers, and psychologists to support our various programs.CENIT, recibe la colaboración de voluntarios ecuatorianos y extranjeros que brindan su apoyo integrándose de manera proactiva en las diferentes áreas y departamentos.RESCATE DE CALLEOffers support and educational opportunities to children and adolescents who find themselves in situations of vulnerability and/or child labor, most notably through our market preschool program. Abordaje de niñas/os y adolescentes en situación de trabajo infantil y/o vulnerabilidad.CENTRO DE APOYO CEAHomework help, tutoring, and recreational activities for child laborers and at-risk children who attend public schools in nearby neighborhoods.Tareas dirigidas, refuerzo escolar y recreación para niñas, niños trabajadores o en situación de riesgo, que asisten a las Escuelas del sector aledaño a CENIT.PRIMARIA “CENIT”Basic primary school education in three years for children and adolescents who have fallen behind and/or dropped out of school, and/or who are in situations of vulnerability.Educación Básica en 3 años para niñas, niños y adolescentes con rezago escolar y en situación de vulnerabilidad, que tengan 8 años de edad, en adelante.CENTRO ARTESANAL “ROSA VIRGINIA”Workshops and classes on various topics related to intestinal production, most notably sewing, jewelry design, and cooking, for adolescents and young people who have already completed the seventh grade.Capacitación en ramas artesanales de Corte-Confección-Bordado y Ebanistería para Adolescentes y jóvenes de 15 años en adelante que han terminado el Séptimo Año de Básica.

story:
Background

I have been working as a teacher for 20 years and have always been interested in tradition and culture and what makes a community.    The aim of this project is to found a place within the local community that gives space to locals to share both within the  community and further afield.   Having organised a few events, where local crafts such a lace making, music and different types of art are involved, I have discovered that there is no set place in which these events can happen.  It is therefore my wish to create such a place that will not only benefit the local community but improve it by bringing a possible tourist attraction to the area. 

Why this area?

The area is rich in tradition and local crafts many of which are dying out.  By opening such a centre new life will be brought to the area and thus offering the opportunity for local economic growth and a re awakening and interest in the crafts that made a community. Not letting crafts that are dying out die and bring opportunities for new crafts to be taught and organised, will bring life and interest back to the area.  

What will the money be used for?

The funding required is to purchase a local building and fund the outfitting to be suitable to be used as a teaching area and as a centre for tourists to come and learn local Italian crafts and traditions, take part in art classes and music courses.   Part of the rewards that are to be offered include free courses, pieces of art work by local artists depicting the area and its natural rural beauty.  

 

If the full funds are not raised the money will be used to fund a smaller community project also based around the arts and crafts of the area.  

What is in place so far?

Through a network of local friends and colleagues I already have offers to hold classes and events, but we need a place to hold them.   A local architect has offered his services for free should the sum be raised and a builder at cost. 

Last thoughts

Ever wished you had listened to or watched more what your grandmother did? Now is your chance not to let other people loose that opportunity too. Everyone can help, no matter how small, every little helps whether you can contribute or help by sharing this project with friends who maybe be able to help.

story:
Our Context

Why ?

Less than 10% of all world-wide Business and Fundraising deals go to immigrants, minority or underprivileged entrepreneurs. Because they don’t have enough resources, trust and network. 

What ?

Do you want to be a part of the solution, join us and invest in diversity the next digital revolution.

Who ?

Are you entrepreneur, intrapreneur, sidepreneur, solopreneur or talent ? 

ConnectX, is a superconnector that makes  business introductions for funders and underrepresented founders.

*Superconnector: Mobile and web application for immigrants and underprivileged founders.

When ?

From 1 October to 1 December

Where ?

On Indiegogo

How ?

A superconnector without biases that curate all good content and makes introductions for 1:1 meetings to advance your business journey. 

*FR : AIDEZ NOUS à développer une application de formation en ligne et de mise en relation pour les diversités.

*ES : AYÚDENOS a desarrollar una aplicación de formación en línea y de creación de redes para la diversidad.

*EN : HELP US develop an online training and networking application for diversity.

 

Our Story

[ YOU CAN DONATE ON PAYPAL: https://www.paypal.com/paypalme/connectx  ]

ConnectX Global is a non-governmental organization founded by Bacely YoroBi, Juan Felipé Mesa, Augusto Moreno and Isa Guipro. It begins its activities in Côte d'Ivoire in 2014 and then expands in France and then in more than 10 countries since 2016.

In 2018, we launch ConnectX Corporation a startup, and a global community platform for inclusion and innovation composed of innovators passionate about fostering a culture of entrepreneurship and tech for good.

We connect immigrants and diverse talents with Funders and give them opportunities.

Our global tech community has more than 1000+ talented entrepreneurs within 10+ cities worldwide, sharing tips, resources, job & freelance opportunities and training.

 

ConnectX is a superconnector that inspire you, train you and connect you to the right investor.

 

More than Just connecting

*ConnectX Features

All rounded Syllabus
 Diversity Matters, How I Make Money, How to create a Brand, An Funder's Perspective. Choose subjects from our vast selection of curriculums.

Fellowship vs Community
After a 4-week virtual program designed for immigrants and diverse talents we still connect and help to grow personally and professionally with their peers.

Algorithm based Contents matching 
Our algorithms will match you to a funder that suits your needs depending on of what you listen and learn. That is our priority, so that you will enjoy every step of your training on ConnectX.

*Our Metrics: 

- In 3 years

- 10 cities

- 15 nationalities

- 210 events

- 300 Speakers from all other the world and 130 founders in our fellowship program

- 300 community partners

- 1,500 Early adopters

- 1,000 hours of conversations

- 5,000 attendees

- 9320 miles covered

Now is the time to support the new generation of minority founders, and give them a platform to make their dream becoming true.

Minority founders have so many things to share support on Indiegogo. 

 

 

 

Support Immigrants and diverse founders !

We have many goals, and each new step can help us grow our impact further.

 

#Goal 0 : With  $10,000 we can organize our hackathon focus on diversity and developing our online platform for minority and underrepresented people. 

#Goal 1 :  With $25,000 Testing & launching our first 100% online innovation program for founders seeking to have a global #impact. 

#Goal 2 :  With $50,000 Developing our Fund I for minority and unrepresented talents. 

#Goal 3 : With $100,500 Creating Fund II and free online coding startup school for for minority and immigrants seeking to have a global #impact. 

#Goal 4 : With $250,500 Introducing our originals shows, films, podcast focus on diversity, and our grants & prizes for minority and unrepresented talents.

 

What Makes ConnectX Special ?

We inspire, We train and We connect immigrants and underestimated to help them growth.

story:
CONJURE IMAGES WITH LANGUAGE 

Have you ever wondered what it would be like if you could just imagine something into being? 

At a time when millions are communicating over social media, WordsEye raises visual expression to an exciting new level: unleashing the power of language to let anyone create pithy political cartoons, compelling visual stories, whimsical greetings, abstract art, or beautiful animations. All done as easily as sending a simple text.

WordsEye is a first-of-its-kind technology that lets anyone — both artists and non-artists —create brilliant visuals by simply describing them.

WordsEye leverages the power of 3D graphics and natural language processing. Descriptive sentences place characters, objects, and lights on a virtual stage. The scene is a "theater-in-the-round" that can be viewed from any angle. Any scene can be opened, edited and then re-rendered; it can even be posted as a visual comment on the original scene that inspired it.

Sample scenes created by WordsEye users

In Transit

Scene Creation Text: Shiny powder blue structure is 2 inches in ground. The ground is 100 foot wide and shiny. 60 feet deep and 30 feet wide floor...

Lightheaded

Scene Creation Text: The 4 foot tall ghost is above the barber chair. the monster is right of the chair. the monster is facing the southwest. the room backdrop.

Solitary Moments

Scene Creation Text: 1st 25 feet long and 2.5 feet tall wood wall. 2nd 25 feet long and 9.5 feet tall clear wall is 0.5 feet below the 1st wall. 1st car is 8 feet left of and 3 feet behind the 1st wall....

Check out our gallery here!

How WordsEye Works — Our Proprietary Technology

At the heart of WordsEye is the parsing of sentences into a semantic representation and a resulting graphical realization. WordsEye uses a proprietary Natural Language Processing (NLP)  system to parse and understand the input text. It then chooses among thousands of 3D models to bring your scene to life. WordsEye scenes can be viewed from any angle, enabling countless creative possibilities.

 

Our Story, So Far…

WordsEye's technology was developed by researchers from Columbia University, led by Bob Coyne who had spent years building software tools for professional 3D artists. These systems, while powerful, were time consuming to use and required artistic and technical skill. So the idea occurred to Bob that he could radically democratize 3D graphics by letting people use language to conjure sophisticated 3D imagery. This would open up new paths of visual expression for everyone, including non-professionals.

In bringing the product to market, the development team was expanded to leverage the skills of Nayan Mohapatra, a graduate of the Columbia Executive MBA program and Gary Zamchick, a cartoonist and illustrator who has created everything from best-selling humor books, to experiences for the Disney Parade, to innovation labs for major corporations.  The company's mission is to unlock the creative potential of humanity by making imaginative visual expression as simple as sending a text message.

What You Will Be Supporting

If you've ever dreamed of being the author of a children's book or graphic novel, or want to engage more meaningfully on social media, or just aspire to become a brilliant word-artist, now is your chance to help us.  Your support will fund improvements to our natural language understanding engine, our inventory of 3D models and locations, and our graphical renderer.  These changes will make WordsEye more powerful and capable of representing all YOU can imagine!

Fostering Creativity and Learning

For kids, the impact of the platform is two-fold: a new form of creative visual expression for their school projects, and a powerful tool to reinforce their writing and reading comprehension. WordsEye has the potential to help young learners refine their literacy and spatial reasoning skills while flexing their imaginations and having fun!

In a pilot study, 5th grade students used WordsEye to create scenes based on stories they were reading in class; their scores on a literacy test were significantly improved. You support will help us bring WordsEye more broadly into K-12 and special education classrooms.

Other Ways You Can Help

Please watch our video and review the perks listed in the column to the right. They include some exciting ways to give us your support!  Please ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about our campaign. Use the Indiegogo share tools to post about us on social media.

story:
Revealing Light is an organization that exists to make the love of Jesus known in the Frogtown and Hamline-Midway neighborhoods of Saint Paul, Minnesota through caring acts of service, direct financial support, loving conversation, and by providing opportunities for people to grow in their relationship with God.


OUR STORY


As a way of illustrating the role of a Christian in the world, author and speaker Michael Frost paints this picture.

Imagine a friend locked in a small room. This room is dirty, dusty, full of clutter. In fact, the dirt is so substantial that the windows in the room are completely and totally covered in grime, so much so that no light from the outside is able to enter the room. Outside the room, the sun is beginning to rise. A beautiful sunrise is quickly developing.  Your friend has never seen a sunrise.  What would you do to show the beauty of the developing sunrise to your friend?  Clean the window! Cleaning the window would allow your friend the ability to see a sunrise for the first time. But the grime is so thick that cleaning the window takes time.  At first, your friend is only able to see a gradual brightening in the room.  Then little bits of orange colored light begin to shine through.  As you clean, more and more of the beautiful sight outside becomes visible and the beauty of the sunrise becomes reality for your friend.

All people have been locked in the room of sin since the Garden of Eden. The outside world, with the sunrise in all it’s glory, is an unknown to those who haven’t met the God of the Bible, known through Jesus. They know nothing of the reality of God’s reign through Christ in the world and in their lives. As those who have come to know the love of God and his reign in our lives, we have the ability, even the responsibility, to clean the windows.  In doing so, we give others a vision, an experience, of what the reign of God is all about.  We both demonstrate and announce the reign of God through Christ.  We are in no way adding to or helping the reign of God into existence.  The sunrise exists in all it’s glory regardless of our action. However, we have the wonderful opportunity to reveal that kingdom, the reign of God, the love of God, in the lives of people. 

The window washing analogy first became part of my own story when attending Wikiconference 2013, a gathering of missional church leaders organized by the Five-Two organization of Katy, Texas. 

What I learned and experienced while at this event, along with other stories of the missional work of God through His people, gave me the words to verbalize a new calling in my life and how I envision living out that call.

As I look back, I can see God working for years to start a fire for missional service in me.

I had failed to recognize it, until recently. 


For the past four summers, I served as a part of the leadership team for an event called UKANDU Chicago, a mission trip where teens and adults serve schools, churches, non-profit organizations, and individuals in inner-city Chicago.  As a member of the leadership team, I learned what is involved in assisting people with a variety of needs and I gained valuable skills in organizing and leading short and long-term service projects. Year three, 2013, was different though.

In year three, I served as the leader of a “street missions team.”  Throughout the week, our team used a variety of random acts of kindness projects to open the door to conversations with residents of the city.  On Thursday afternoon, in the midst of a late lunch, our group met Ryan, a thirty-something drug addict. Through the course of a lengthy conversation with Ryan, we learned his story, and he was able to hear our stories - and about our God.  Near the end of the conversation, I bluntly asked Ryan, “Do you want to get better?  Do you want that old life you described back again?  Would you let us help you?”  In a tentative willingness that surprised the members of our group, including me, Ryan responded, “Yes.  Okay.”  So off we went, loading Ryan into our van and taking him to a drug treatment center.

This small group of teens revealed a little of God’s love to Ryan.  Although Ryan confessed knowing about Jesus, it was all cognitive; I doubt that God’s great love had ever been a reality his life.  Until that afternoon.

For me, this further fanned the flame of God’s new calling in my life.


Less than a month after UKANDU Chicago 2013, I was on vacation with my family in Minnesota.  Sunday afternoon, my wife Angela and I were meeting friends for conversation and a chance to catch up on the happenings of each other’s lives. It was a beautiful August day and we decided to meet at the playground of a school near their home, located in the Hamline-Midway neighborhood.  As I was sitting there waiting for our friend to arrive and our kids were getting settled into playing on the playground, I had a clear sense that God was telling me, in a nearly audible voice, “Come here and do mission.  This is your mission field.”

And yet, I still had no sense of what mission work in the Frogtown and Midway neighborhoods of Saint Paul would look like.  Until attending Wikiconference 2013. Piece by piece, as I listened to each presenter, God revealed a picture of my service as a figurative window washer and what that would look like.


Michael Frost shared the following story about a young pastor he met in Cambodia named Abraham Hang, also recorded his book, The Road to Missional:

A few years ago I met Pastor Abraham Hang on a leadership conference in Phnom Penh...  When I asked him how he got started, he told me he simply asked the Lord what he should do to create a foretaste of the world to come among the poverty and desperation of Andong Resettlement Village. The Lord told him to dry out the muddy swamp underfoot, a breeding ground for mosquitoes and disease.  And so, Abraham, together with men of the village, and helped by Christian men from around about, dug deep trenches to drain away the water left during the wet season to dry out the land and make life more bearable.

Then he arranged for Christian doctors and dentists to bring mobile clinics Andong, believing as he did that in the world to come that would be no sickness or disease... Then he found the funding through a local missionary to build hundreds of thatch-roof houses because he was convinced that in the world to come no one will live under corrugated iron in temperatures of 100 degrees and 100 percent humidity. Then, because public transportation costs made it prohibitive for the men of the village to get into the city to look for day jobs as menial laborers, Abraham raised the money to buy a truck in order to drive them there and back each morning and evening.

I walked through narrow and winding streets of Andong with Abraham one day, struggling with the heat and flies, but amazed by the transformation the gospel had brought that place. As we wandered these streets, residents would appear in with their hands together before their faces in the traditional Cambodian greeting, they would begin to speak to me unprompted and enthusiastically in Khmer, which I can’t understand. Abraham felt obliged to translate as he sheepishly reported that they were telling me about the change that occurred in their lives since they had come to [understand] the universal reign of God in Christ.


I envision intentionally and systematically visiting the residents of the Midway and Frogtown neighborhood at their homes, in the neighborhood stores, in parks and other public places. With each interaction, I would ask, in one form or another, what could be done in their life, that would make the reign of God a reality to them.  Of course, for many of the people I would meet, God himself is either a threatening of foreign idea. This question would need to be reworked, rephrased, and sometimes translated with each conversation. But the meaning would stay the same: What window in your life needs to be washed so you would be able to recognize the beauty of God’s love and His reign in the world?

My experiences in Chicago have shown me that questions like this will often reveal needs that can be met with some creativity, hard work, and partnerships with existing community services.

With each window discovered, a plan for cleaning that window would be developed and implemented.  Area congregations, social service agencies, local companies, even governmental entities could be contacted to play a role in alleviating the issue or issues identified by individual neighborhood residents.

Congregational volunteers, employees of local companies, and representatives of neighborhood organizations will be mobilized to work, not for, but alongside neighborhood residents, following the highly successful work partnership model of Habitat for Humanity.

At the same time, residents will be encouraged to use their gifts and talents for service on other projects, providing opportunities for them to give back to their community at the same time as they receive support.

Members of area congregations who express an interest in ongoing service with this ministry would be trained to wash windows.  That is, they would be trained in how to share the love of God through gentle and respectful faith conversations in the midst of service and work, ensuring our work doesn't become like that of any other social service organization but that a proper balance between demonstration and proclamation of God’s love is found.

In addition, members of neighborhood partner congregations who feel called to a deeper level of service through discipleship will be invited to be a part of an intentional discipleship process, with a two-fold goal:  to multiply leaders within this ministry and provide discipleship mentors for those who feel called to follow Jesus at a deeper level through contact with this ministry.


FUNDING INFORMATION

Start Up Fund

Revealing Light will need donations totaling $11,000 to begin operations, $3400 of which has already been realized.  Monies donated toward our start-up fund have set aside to file the proper legal paperwork necessary for Revealing Light to operate as a non-profit entity [already complete], purchase the tech equipment and software needed for the efficient operation of Revealing Light, pay for the first retreat of the Board of Directors, and allow us to begin our initial fundraising efforts for our Operational Fund.


Operational Fund

To sustain the ongoing operations of Revealing Light, we are seeking $22,000 per year to fully fund the Operational Fund. The Operational Fund of Revealing Light will be used to fund the four aspects of our mission statement:  [1] caring acts of service, [2] direct financial support, [3] sharing the love of Jesus, and [4] and for providing opportunities for people to grow in their relationship with God - through discussion groups, classes, and the like.

Some examples of how these monies might be used:  food assistance, purchasing supplies for home repair, financial assistance for attending community education classes or children's programs, resources for leading discipleship groups, and more. 

In addition, the Operational Fund will pay for supplies used by Revealing Light, including coffee, water, paper and ink.  It will also pay for the hosting of the web site, email accounts for leadership team members, software upgrades as needed, and annual Board of Directors retreats.


A Few Notes

All monies donated, unless otherwise specified by the donor, will be used to fund the Start-up Fund until the funding goal of $11,000 is fully realized; at that point, monies donated will be used to fund the Operational Fund.

100% of donations to Revealing Light will be used for the funding of the ministry itself.  Support for Jim and his family will come from outside employment, "tentmaking" if you will.

Revealing Light is an organization that exists to make the love of Jesus known in the Frogtown and Hamline-Midway neighborhoods of Saint Paul, Minnesota through caring acts of service, direct financial support, loving conversation, and by providing opportunities for people to grow in their relationship with God.OUR STORYAs a way of illustrating the role of a Christian in the world, author and speaker Michael Frost paints this picture.Imagine a friend locked in a small room. This room is dirty, dusty, full of clutter. In fact, the dirt is so substantial that the windows in the room are completely and totally covered in grime, so much so that no light from the outside is able to enter the room. Outside the room, the sun is beginning to rise. A beautiful sunrise is quickly developing.  Your friend has never seen a sunrise.  What would you do to show the beauty of the developing sunrise to your friend?  Clean the window! Cleaning the window would allow your friend the ability to see a sunrise for the first time. But the grime is so thick that cleaning the window takes time.  At first, your friend is only able to see a gradual brightening in the room.  Then little bits of orange colored light begin to shine through.  As you clean, more and more of the beautiful sight outside becomes visible and the beauty of the sunrise becomes reality for your friend.All people have been locked in the room of sin since the Garden of Eden. The outside world, with the sunrise in all it’s glory, is an unknown to those who haven’t met the God of the Bible, known through Jesus. They know nothing of the reality of God’s reign through Christ in the world and in their lives.
